headline: Google Buys Web Video Software Firm
abstract: Google said on Wednesday it agreed to buy On2 Technologies, which sells video compression software, in a stock deal valued at about $106 million.

headline: Who Is the Small Business Majority?
abstract: The organization has gotten a lot of press this spring, first as one of two small business invitees to the White House health care summit in March. But just what is Small Business Majority, and whom does it really represent?

headline: Amid Investor Wariness, 2 REITs Halve Their I.P.O
abstract: Two private-equity backed real estate investment trusts found themselves cutting their planned initial public offerings by half Wednesday, amid tepid investor response.

headline: Is the A.I.G. Rally a Little Early?
abstract: For American International Group, a return to health looks a long way off — and any investment return to taxpayers is even more distant, Breakingviews says.

headline: Q & A: Big Pain From Small Keyboards
abstract: Ways to expand the keyboard on your tiny, tiny netbook.

headline: Kraft’s Bid for Cadbury Propels European Stocks
abstract: Investors jumped into equities on Monday, sending shares up around the world, while the dollar weakened as demand for riskier assets took hold.

headline: Coming Soon: Lehman Brothers, the Movie
abstract: The BBC said on Wednesday that it is producing “The Last Days of Lehman Brothers,” a TV movie “inspired by the real events” of that September weekend when the storied investment bank fell.

headline: Hoberman Hunting Start-Ups in Europe
abstract: PROfounders co-founder Brent Hoberman is on vacation with a mission: Scouring Europe for the most energetic and disruptive businesses around, The Daily Telegraph reported.

headline: Apple Lifts the Curtain on App Store Approvals
abstract: Apple’s response to the F.C.C. inquiry into the rejection of the Google Voice iPhone app cracked the veneer of the App Store review process.

headline: Balsillie Raises Coyotes Bid by $30 Million
abstract: From Slap Shot: James L. Balsillie, the Canadian billionaire who was already offering $212.5 million to buy the Phoenix Coyotes — some $62 million more than the next-highest bid — increased his offer by another $30 million.

headline: The Post-Lehman Deal Landscape
abstract: The year since Lehman collapsed has brought many changes for Wall Street, including the part that works on deals.

headline: Abu Dhabi Fund Buys Stake in Tesla Motors
abstract: Daimler has sold a 4 percent stake in Tesla Motors, the all-electric sports car company, to Abu Dhabi’s Aabar Investments, the two companies said.

headline: Dell Rejects a Strategy Popular With Rivals
abstract: While other major technology players appear set on a grand consolidation scheme, Dell will focus on smaller acquisitions, Ashlee Vance writes for Bits.

headline: Santander to Raise Up to $7.2 Billion in Brazil Sale
abstract: Banco Santander, Spain’s largest bank, aims to raise as much as 13.1 billion reais ($7.2 billion) by selling shares in its Brazilian unit.

headline: Southwest Airlines Plans to Bid for Frontier
abstract: Southwest Airlines said Thursday it was preparing a bid, valued at a minimum of $113.6 million, for its low-fare rival Frontier Airlines, which sought bankruptcy protection in April 2008.

headline: UBS Said to Be Advising Baer on Bid for ING Units
abstract: Julius Baer has hired UBS to advise on a possible bid for ING Groep’s private banking units in Asia and Europe, sources told Reuters.

headline: 3i Arranges New Credit Lines
abstract: 3i Group, the publicly-listed European buyout shop, said that the pace if its new investments had fallen 75 percent due to the scarcity of debt financing.

headline: Swiss Ease Bank Secrecy in Treaty With Britain
abstract: Switzerland and Britain signed a new treaty that gives British tax authorities more access to banking information, and brings Switzerland closer to being removed from a list of international tax havens.

headline: C.I.C. Turns to Morgan Stanley and Blackstone
abstract: China Investment Corp.’s $200 billion sovereign-wealth fund has chosen Morgan Stanley and Blackstone to oversee hundreds of millions of dollars in new investments, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: The Make-Believe ABC House Is Getting Crowded
abstract: An imaginative campaign from ABC to promote its series for the 2009-10 season is being expanded. The campaign, which began in May, is centered on the fanciful notion that the stars of all the shows broadcast by ABC live together in a house as one big happy family.

headline: CIT Announces Its $3 Billion Rescue Plan
abstract: As the market waits for the CIT Group to formally announce its lifeline from a group of some of its biggest bondholders, DealBook has learned several more details about the plan.

headline: Which Colleges Are Doing Their Job?
abstract: Three ways to see which colleges (like the University of California campuses) excel at turning students into graduates and which colleges (like the University of Louisville) do not.

headline: The Strange Destiny of Mortgage Bonds at S&P
abstract: Reversing its evaluation of a group of mortgage bonds backed by commercial property, Standard & Poor’s lifted the ratings Tuesday on several securities it downgraded a week ago, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Sizing Up Goldman’s Bonus Pool
abstract: Profits at Goldman Sachs have made a roaring comeback — and it seems that the Wall Street firm’s legendary bonus pool has as well.

headline: EMC Wins Data Domain With $2.4 Billion Offer
abstract: With a $2.4 billion bid, EMC finally beat out NetApp, its archrival in the storage business, to acquire Data Domain and its deduplication technology.

headline: PennyMac I.P.O. Falls Short of Fund-Raising Goal
abstract: PennyMac Mortgage Investment Trust, a firm set up by former Countrywide Financial executives, fell short of its fund-raising goal in an I.P.O..

headline: House Members Have More Questions for Goldman
abstract: The controversy surrounding Goldman Sachs continues. The New York Post reported a bipartisan congressional group suggested the bank had accepted taxpayer dollars then increased risk in order to pay big bonuses.

headline: Q & A: Decoding Memory Card Ratings
abstract: The number in the class rating on an SD memory card— Class 2, Class 4 or even Class 10 — refers to the rate megabytes are transferred.

headline: Ex-Moody’s Employee Warned S.E.C. On Municipal Bonds
abstract: As Congress steps up scrutiny of the credit rating industry, allegations by another former employee of Moody’s Investors Service have come to light and the big rating agency is being called to account before a House panel.

headline: Joy Behar to Make Her HLN Debut
abstract: Joy Behar takes over the 9 p.m. time slot on HLN Tuesday night.

headline: Babcock Creditors Clear Way for Potential Inquiry
abstract: Creditors of the bankrupt Australian investment firm Babcock & Brown Ltd. voted Monday to liquidate its assets, paving the way for a possible inquiry into a deal struck between Babcock’s management and a syndicate of 25 banks.

headline: Google and Amazon Increasingly at Odds Over E-Books
abstract: Google makes one million books available on a Kindle rival as Amazon files opposition to Google’s settlement with authors and publishers.

headline: Goldman Said to Be Subpoenaed Over Weekly Tips
abstract: Goldman Sachs has been subpoenaed by the Massachusetts chief financial regulator who demands information on the firm’s weekly meetings where analysts offer tips to traders and big clients, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Bridgewater Leads in Investor Survey
abstract: Bridgewater Associates, the giant hedge fund based in Connecticut, scored the top spot in a new survey asking institutional investors which they thought were the best of the big hedge fund firms.

headline: Roll Call to Buy Congressional Quarterly
abstract: The owner of Roll Call is buying Congressional Quarterly in a deal that will bring two well-known publications covering Capitol Hill and Washington politics under the same corporate umbrella.

headline: Amaranth Settles With Regulators
abstract: Amaranth, the multibillion-dollar hedge fund that collapsed in 2006, agreed to pay $7.5 million to settle regulators’ allegations that it tried to manipulate natural gas prices.

headline: Marathon Tech Review: Gadgets to Prevent Injury
abstract: Online resources that offer guidance on preventing injuries and can help us recover faster from the aches and pains.

headline: Who Said TV Wasn’t Educational?
abstract: The EyeClops Bionic Eye SE can turn your television into a large-screen microscope.

headline: Fitch Downgrades Comerica Debt on Credit Costs
abstract: Fitch Ratings on Wednesday cut Comerica’s investment-grade debt ratings, saying the bank’s profitability is increasingly threatened by higher credit costs and the recession.

headline: Deutsche’s Profits Rise, but Loan Provisions Jump
abstract: Deutsche Bank said Tuesday that its second-quarter net profit rose sharply from a year earlier as its securities trading business recovered from the credit bust.

headline: Roboboat?
abstract: A big, armed remote controlled boat that could combat the growing risk from piracy.

headline: Wellstream Sells Onshore Pipeline Unit
abstract: Wellstream Holdings, oil services group, agreed to sell an onshore pipeline technology unit as part of plans to focus on its offshore operations.

headline: Inuit Tribe and Oaktree Said to Warm to PPIP Fund
abstract: Under a plan designed to help financial institutions get rid of toxic assets, the Inupiat Eskimos of Alaska’s North Slope will partner with Oaktree Capital Management to enter the Public-Private Investment Program, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Porsche May Not Decide on VW Deal This Week
abstract: The takeover drama between Porsche and Volkswagen may not be resolved this week, despite the upcoming board meeting scheduled for July 23, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: 5AM Ventures Exceeds $150 Million Goal for 3rd Fund
abstract: 5AM Ventures, which focuses on early-stage investments in life sciences, has exceeding the $150 million fund-raising target for its third fund.

headline: Barnes & Noble to Buy Firm From Chairman
abstract: Barnes & Noble said it would buy a firm that operates college bookstores from Barnes & Noble’s chairman in a deal worth $596 million.

headline: Almost $1 Billion Demanded Back in Stanford Case
abstract: About 500 Stanford Financial Group investors and 66 former advisers should return nearly $1 billion in order to divide it amongst people whose investments disappeared in a scam allegedly perpetrated by the firm, a court-appointed receiver told a judge Tuesday.

headline: P.E. Firm to Vie With Nokia Siemens for Nortel
abstract: In the first of several auctions, bidders will convene Friday at a New York law firm to compete for parts of bankrupt Nortel Networks’ wireless telephone equipment business.

headline: Top 1% Paid More in Federal Income Taxes Than Bottom 95% in ’07
abstract: The top 1 percent of taxpayers paid 40.42 percent of federal income taxes in 2007, according to the most recent data from the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Dynamics Gets $5.7 Million in First Round
abstract: Dynamics, a payment card start-up, has landed $5.7 million in a first round of funding led by Adams Capital Management.

headline: Surprise! Mort Zuckerman Wants BusinessWeek, Too
abstract: The owner of U.S. News and World Report bid at the last minute bidder for the magazine, being sold by McGraw-Hill.

headline: Asset Freeze Holds, for Now, in Michigan Ponzi Case
abstract: A lawyer pleaded with a judge to carve out a $3,000 allowance for a Michigan money manager whose assets were frozen after federal regulators accused him of squandering millions of dollars of his clients’ money on a lavish lifestyle.

headline: F.D.I.C. Says Bank Failures Will Cost $100 Billion
abstract: Federal regulators said Tuesday they expected bank failures to cost the deposit insurance fund about $100 billion in the next four years, much higher than the earlier estimate of $70 billion in failure costs through 2013.

headline: Creative Audio Downsizing
abstract: A new entry into audio streaming, and a bargain at that.

headline: Apple Polishes the iPod Lineup
abstract: Apple revamps the iPods, lowers some prices, adds some features

headline: Swiss Bank to Leave U.S. Amid Tighter Restrictions
abstract: Wegelin, the Swiss private bank, said Tuesday that it was pulling out of the United States amid stricter measures against tax dodgers.

headline: HSBC May Be in Talks for Hong Kong Banking Venture
abstract: HSBC is in advanced talks with China’s Industrial Securities to create an investment banking venture, Reuters said, citing a report from Hong Kong’s Apple Daily.

headline: Six From Sky Capital Charged in $140 Million Fraud
abstract: Six employees of a Wall Street retail broker, Sky Capital, ran a $140 million “trans-Atlantic boiler room” to defraud investors in the U.S. and Britain, authorities said.

headline: R.B.S. Said to Consider Sale of Aircraft Leasing Unit
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland has hired Goldman Sachs to consider a sale of or other options for RBS Aviation Capital, one of the world’s biggest plane leasing businesses, news reports said Tuesday.

headline: Hedge Fund Name May Give Pause to Investors
abstract: A new hedge fund plans to begin trading next year. But its name, Ground Zero Strategic Commodities, may concern investors.

headline: Panasonic Adds New Technology to 3 Models
abstract: Panasonic adds fast start up, auto focus to three new Lumix cameras.

headline: Court Says Lehman Can Pursue Claims on C.D.O.s
abstract: Lehman Brothers can pursue claims on assets in a bankruptcy case expected to set a precedent for treatment of derivatives in complex investment products, a New York court said Tuesday.

headline: Pushing the Limits of Stimulus Plans
abstract: In the beginning, there was only a financial crisis. When the subprime mortgage market blew up in August 2007, few economists worried about the wider impact. In retrospect, that serenity was foolish, Breakingviews writes.

headline: Kuwaiti Islamic Bank Returns to Investing in U.S.
abstract: Kuwait’s largest Islamic bank said Sunday that it has signed a $450 million deal with a U.S. real estate investment trust to buy high-income residential real estate in major U.S. cities.

headline: All the News That Fits, Sony Style
abstract: Sony expands it e-book reader line with a larger device and wireless networking.

headline: Philips’ New 3-in-1… Thing
abstract: All of you who were waiting for a laptop-rest/beanbag/loudspeaker? Your prayers have been answered.

headline: Chrysler Turnaround Slow-Going, Fiat Chief Says
abstract: Chrysler Group will present a five-year business plan by the end of November that outlines numbers and the path out of two years of difficulties, its chief executive said on Wednesday.

headline: Paltalk Buys Stake Back from Softbank
abstract: Paltalk, the video-based social networking start-up, is buying back the 20 percent stake it sold to Softbank for $6 million in its second round five years ago, PaidContent.org reported.

headline: Philippine Development Bank May Start V.C. Fund
abstract: The Development Bank of the Philippines is considering the creation of a venture capital fund that would provide financing to small businesses, BusinessWorld Online reported.

headline: Intel Says Europe Erred in Levying $1.4 Billion Fine
abstract: The Intel Corporation, the computer chip maker, is claiming in court documents that European Union regulators made serious mistakes in levying a record fine of 1.06 billion euros ($1.45 billion) last May on a charge of illegally restricting a competitor.

headline: Google Buys Web Video Software Firm
abstract: Google said on Wednesday it agreed to buy On2 Technologies, which sells video compression software, in a stock deal valued at about $106 million.

abstract: Two private-equity backed real estate investment trusts found themselves cutting their planned initial public offerings by half Wednesday, amid tepid investor response.

abstract: PROfounders co-founder Brent Hoberman is on vacation with a mission: Scouring Europe for the most energetic and disruptive businesses around, The Daily Telegraph reported.

abstract: Apple’s response to the F.C.C. inquiry into the rejection of the Google Voice iPhone app cracked the veneer of the App Store review process.

headline: Balsillie Raises Coyotes Bid by $30 Million
abstract: From Slap Shot: James L. Balsillie, the Canadian billionaire who was already offering $212.5 million to buy the Phoenix Coyotes — some $62 million more than the next-highest bid — increased his offer by another $30 million.

headline: The Wattage Riddle
abstract: Why do the labels on many electronic products omit the wattage?

headline: A New Smartphone Accessory Is for Your Eyes Only
abstract: A film from 3M that obscures your phone’s screen from casual busybodies is now available in custom sizes for most phones.

headline: So Long CPU Wars. It Was Fun.
abstract: With a new marketing campaign, Advanced Micro Devices has decided to tout its graphics chips over its CPUs, ending many years of battling over technical specs with Intel.

headline: Appaloosa and Icahn Are Said to Consider Bids for Delphi
abstract: Appaloosa Management and Carl C. Icahn are among four bidders that may make offers Thursday for Delphi, the bankrupt auto-parts maker, The New York Post reported.

headline: S.E.C. Watchdog’s Bite Not Matching Its Bark?
abstract: Is the new cop on the securities beat armed with a peashooter? The size of the penalties recently meted out by Mary Schapiro and her team at the the S.E.C. gives that impression, Breakingviews writes.

headline: Cerberus Said to Control Maxim Publisher
abstract: The Quandrangle Group, the private equity firm founded by Steven Rattner, has given up on its investment in Alpha Group, publisher of Maxim magazine, The New York Post reported.

headline: Obama Strikes Out at Wall Street Banks
abstract: President Barack Obama said that Wall Street banks had failed to show remorse for the “wild risks” that triggered a financial meltdown and helped to push the United States into recession.

headline: Thursday Ratings: Crime and ‘Brother’ Put CBS on Top
abstract: Crime show repeats and “Big Brother” helped CBS rank No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, CBS’s reruns of “CSI” and “The Mentalist” delivered the night’s most viewers with 7.5 million and 8.4 million viewers, respectively, at 9 and 10 p.m.

headline: Surprise! Zuckerman Wants BusinessWeek, Too
abstract: From Media Decoder: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The New York Daily News, is a surprise last-minute bidder.

headline: CrossMedia Receives $17 Million to Refinance Debt
abstract: Cross MediaWorks has secured an investment of $17 million from BIA Digital Partners II and Spring Capital Partners II, The Washington Business Journal reported.

headline: S.B.A. Lending: Down, but Looking Up
abstract: The good news is that the stimulus appears to be working, at least as far as the S.B.A.’s slice of the economy is concerned.

headline: Swedbank to Raise $2.1 Billion to Shore Up Business
abstract: Swedbank, one of the largest Nordic lenders, announced Monday that it is issuing preferred stock to raise about $2.1 billion to shore up its core business as loan losses continue in the eastern Baltic.

headline: NBC, Home of ‘Talent,’ Gets Susan Boyle Interview
abstract: The singer Susan Boyle has granted her first in-depth interview to Meredith Vieira of NBC’s “Today” show, the network said today. Next week “Today” will use the interview to promote “America’s Got Talent,” the stateside edition of the talent show that made Ms. Boyle a worldwide star.

headline: Too Small to Fail?
abstract: Many small companies are going out of business needlessly because they do not know what they do not know. They need more counseling and less talk of “cleansing.”

headline: Political Dynasties, Addendum
abstract: One in 10 members of Congress has relatives who also served, according to an analysis by Muckety.com.

headline: National Bank of Canada Posts Higher Profit
abstract: National Bank of Canada said Thursday that its profit rose 6 percent in the third quarter as trading revenues surged, surpassing estimates.

headline: A New Kind of Protectionism
abstract: A The Tonight Show sketch on Mark Sanford.

headline: Save Your TV Pennies Until November
abstract: Retailers say that consumer electronics pricing on this year’s Black Friday could be the most aggressive in years.

headline: Artists Find Backers as Labels Wane
abstract: Polyphonic, a music venture armed with seed money, is sidestepping industry giants and inventing new ways for artists to make and market their music.

headline: Not Quite So Many Million-Dollar Bonuses at JPMorgan
abstract: New York’s attorney general slightly overstated the number of million-dollar-plus bonuses at JPMorgan Chase in Thursday’s report on bank compensation. DealBook has the real figure.

headline: Ballmer Criticizes I.B.M.’s High-Profit Diet
abstract: Microsoft chief Steve Ballmer criticized I.B.M.’s decisions over the last decade to dispose of its networking equipment, hard disk and PC businesses.

headline: The Citizenship of the Uninsured
abstract: About one-fifth of those who lack medical insurance in the United States are not American citizens, and it remains to be seen how they will fare in health-care reform, an economist writes.

headline: Canon Introduces 6 New PowerShots
abstract: New additions to a line of point-and-shoot digital cameras offer 20X ultrazoom, a slim model with a fast lens and a touch-screen snapper.

headline: Calls Grow in Europe to Limit Bonuses
abstract: Seven European finance leaders have called for far-reaching curbs on bonuses for bankers in a strongly worded draft paper to be presented at a meeting on Friday of G-20 ministers in London.

headline: MGM Replaces Chief, Hires Turnaround Pro
abstract: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the troubled studio behind “The Wizard of Oz” and the James Bond franchise, said Tuesday that it has replaced its chief executive and hired a veteran turnaround expert as part of an effort to restructure itself and cope with a $3.7 billion debt load.

headline: HSBC Said to Hire Adviser for Its Shanghai I.P.O.
abstract: HSBC Holdings is said to have hired China International Capital Corp. to advise it in its bid to be the first foreign company to sell shares in Shanghai, Bloomberg News reported, and could raise up to $5 billion with the issue.

headline: Judge Rejects Settlement Over Merrill Bonuses
abstract: As President Obama traveled to Wall Street on Monday and chided bankers for their recklessness, across town a federal judge issued a far sharper rebuke, not just for some of the financiers but for their regulators in Washington as well. Giving voice to the anger and frustration of many ordinary Americans, Judge Jed S. Rakoff issued a scathing ruling on one of the watershed moments of the financial crisis: the star-crossed takeover of Merrill Lynch by the now-struggling Bank of America.

headline: When Medicare Was Defeated (Again and Again)
abstract: A history of covering the elderly, from Truman to Johnson — with a pause for Reagan.

headline: Bankruptcy for Indebted East Star Airlines
abstract: East Star Airlines, a heavily indebted private airline based in Wuhan, central China, was declared bankrupt after the rejection of its restructuring application on Thursday.

headline: Bank of America Said to Balk at Fees for Merrill Guarantees
abstract: Bank of America is trying to avoid paying billions of dollars in fees to U.S. taxpayers for guarantees against losses at Merrill Lynch, saying the rescue agreement was never signed and the funds never used, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Bank of Choice Raises $15 Million
abstract: Bank of Choice has raised $15 million through a common stock offering, The Denver Business Journal reported, citing bank officials.

headline: Update: Blum Says He’s Not NYTPicker
abstract: Earlier, we posted that David Blum, a veteran of New York media circles and a former editor of The Village Voice, The New York Press and New York magazine, was behind NYTPick.com, an anonymous commentary blog, according to a person with close ties to the site who also requested anonymity.

headline: BofA Moves to Reduce Dependence on Aid
abstract: One year and two bailouts later, with the financial industry on the mend, Bank of America announced several measures on Monday to reduce its reliance on federal aid and to extricate itself from Washington’s grip.

headline: Tuesday Ratings: ‘Talent,’ Crime and Jackson Coverage
abstract: The three major television networks broadcast another round of prime time specials commemorating Michael Jackson on Tuesday, but none of the programs could measure up in the ratings to CBS’s crime show repeats or “America’s Got Talent” on NBC.

headline: Coherex Gets $16.5 Million Injection
abstract: Coherex Medical has raised $16.5 million in a Series B round of financing co-led by Oxford Bioscience Partners and vSpring Capital, The Boston Business Journal reported.

headline: Boys of Heaven
abstract: In Diyala Province, whispers of jihadi training camps for the training of adults and children alike.

headline: Reliance May Be Planning $10 Billion Telecom Deal
abstract: Reliance Communications of India is in preliminary talks to buy the African operations of Kuwaiti telecom Zain, Reuters said, in a deal reported to be worth $10 billion.

headline: Green Dollars Move to Smart Grid and Energy Storage
abstract: The U.S. green technology sector, which suffered a drop in financing this year, is seeing renewed interest with venture dollars flowing in once again to promising startups and companies looking to resurrect delayed public offerings, Reuters reported.

headline: Skype Founders Escalate Legal Battle
abstract: The founders of Skype appear to be scorching the Earth in an effort to assert their interests in eBay’s high-profile sale of the Internet calling service.

headline: Forget a ‘Second’ Stimulus. Stop the First One!
abstract: While some argue that more stimulus is needed, the deepening jobless rate really shows that the cost of stimulus measures far exceeds their benefits, an economist writes.

headline: Gates Foundation Pledges $35 Million for Banking Innovation
abstract: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the world’s richest charitable foundation, this week announced an effort to bring banking, including savings accounts, to the poor.

headline: Checking In on Diller’s Spinoffs
abstract: Barry Diller has an anniversary today: It’s been one year since he split his media and Internet conglomerate into five separate companies, reversing course after years of deal-making that created IAC/InterActiveCorp.

headline: Expectations High for Emdeon I.P.O., Report Says
abstract: This week’s initial public offering of medical billing system Emdeon is drawing high expectations, The Wall Street Journal reported. The company is coming to market just as a health-care overhaul is being hashed out, and electronic processors like Emdeon may benefit.

headline: Mint C.E.O. Eyes Canada and Britain for Expansion
abstract: Mint.com, the personal finance site that has racked up 1.4 million users in the United States, might expand up north and across the pond early next year, its founder and C.E.O. Aaron Patzer said.

headline: Another View: Tunneling to True Profit in China
abstract: How do you put a value on a private Chinese company? Very carefully, says Mark Dixon, a founder of a mergers and acquisitions adviser who unearthed some accounting quirks while valuing a local business.

headline: Quantcast Looks to Raise $50 Million, Report Says
abstract: Quantcast, Web analytics start-up, is seeking to raise about $50 million at a $300 million pre-money valuation, peHUB reported.

headline: A New Venture Firm’s ‘Secret Plan’
abstract: A new venture capital fund, Andreessen Horowitz, plans to watch which start-ups get acquired too early and then look for similar companies that are still innovating independently.

headline: Russian Hedge Funder Finally Leaves the Plaza
abstract: Andrei Vavilov, who took on the developer of the renovated Plaza in one of the most heated real estate disputes in recent Manhattan history, has sold his unit, according to The New York Observer.

headline: Tribune’s Sale of Cubs May Be Rounding Third
abstract: Tribune Co. and the Ricketts family are said to be close to completing all legal documents associated with the sale of the Chicago Cubs baseball team, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Cooper-Standard Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Cooper-Standard Automotive, a troubled auto parts supplier co-owned by Goldman Sachs and the Cypress Group, filed for bankruptcy in Delaware on Monday after reaching a prearranged deal with its creditors over a reorganization plan.

headline: Bankruptcy Judge Approves Lender’s Bid for Delphi
abstract: A bankruptcy judge approved Delphi‘s plan to hand control of the big auto parts supplier to its lenders and soon end a nearly four-year passage through Chapter 11 protection.

headline: Texas Monthly’s Longtime Editor Leaves the Magazine for a Local Web Start-up
abstract: Evan Smith, Texas Monthly’s longtime editor, leaves the magazine to join a Web start-up in Austin, Tex., dedicated to local news.

headline: Britain Said to Be Near Choice for New Chair of Lloyds
abstract: Sir Winfried F.W. Bischoff, former chairman and interim chief executive of Citigroup, is being considered to become next chairman of Lloyds Banking Group, people familiar with the selection process told The Financial Times.

headline: Tweeting for Dollars
abstract: Izea, an online marketing firm, has begun paying Twitter users for sending sponsored tweets to their followers.

headline: Buying Shares in Private Start-Ups
abstract: Small investment managers are popping up to buy shares in privately held social networks like Facebook, attracting millions of dollars from investors.

headline: Facebook Says Its Finances Are Looking Up
abstract: Facebook, the rapidly growing social network, said it had passed an important financial milestone and become cash-flow positive, which indicates it now brings in enough revenue to cover its operating costs.

headline: Woori Denies It Is Close to Blackstone Investment
abstract: Woori Finance Holdings has denied a report that said it was close to investing about $300 million in a private equity fund Blackstone is raising, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Wartime Soldier, Conflicted Mom
abstract: Lizette Alvarez reports on the unique challenges faced by mothers in the military in the latest article in the Women at Arms series.

headline: For News Corp., Fox News Is Now Major Player
abstract: If it weren’t for the financial success of Fox News, overseen by Roger Ailes, the media conglomerate would be in a deep crisis.

headline: Auto-Tune Isn’t Dead. It’s Coming to Your iPhone
abstract: A pitch-correcting app for the iPhone will lift your voice into the roboticized harmony you’ve only dreamed about.

abstract: Google said on Wednesday it agreed to buy On2 Technologies, which sells video compression software, in a stock deal valued at about $106 million.

abstract: Apple’s response to the F.C.C. inquiry into the rejection of the Google Voice iPhone app cracked the veneer of the App Store review process.

headline: Balsillie Raises Coyotes Bid by $30 Million
abstract: From Slap Shot: James L. Balsillie, the Canadian billionaire who was already offering $212.5 million to buy the Phoenix Coyotes — some $62 million more than the next-highest bid — increased his offer by another $30 million.

headline: Bank of America Seeks to Lure Merrill Bankers, Report Says
abstract: Bank of America is mounting a campaign to rehire several of the more than three dozen senior Merrill Lynch investment bankers who quit after the firms merged, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Southeast Asia’s Biggest Bank’s Profit in Retreat
abstract: DBS Group Holdings, Southeast Asia’s biggest bank, posted a 15 percent decline in second-quarter profit as provisions for bad loans surged.

headline: Penske Ends Talks to Buy Saturn From G.M.
abstract: A deal to buy the brand from General Motors was abruptly called off, citing difficulties in getting the cars built.

headline: Morgan Stanley Said to Plan Hiring Spree
abstract: Morgan Stanley is planning to hire as many as 400 traders and salespeople, a hiring spree that comes as the firm tries to dig its way out of three straight quarters of losses.

headline: Beijing Court Convicts Ex-Sinopec Chief of Bribery
abstract: The former chairman of Sinopec, the largest oil refiner in Asia, was convicted of corruption by a court in Beijing on Wednesday, according to the Chinese news agency Xinhua.

headline: Russian Billionaire Signs Deal to Buy the Nets
abstract: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, a Russian billionaire, an amateur basketball player the size of an N.B.A. power forward, signed a tentative $200 million deal Wednesday that would make him the principal owner of the New Jersey Nets and an investor in the team’s new home, an arena planned for Brooklyn.

headline: Hartford Taps Ex-BofA Executive to Be Its New Chief
abstract: The Hartford Financial Services Group announced that a former top executive of Bank of America, Liam E. McGee, would take over as chairman and chief executive on Thursday.

headline: Britain’s Balfour Beatty Buys Parsons Brinckerhoff
abstract: A British construction company, Balfour Beatty, said Thursday that it had agreed to buy the New York transportation engineering group Parsons Brinckerhoff for $626 million.

headline: Barclays Capital May Split Assets of P.E. Division
abstract: Barclays Capital may split the assets of its mid-market private equity division, Barclays Private Equity, and the management company which runs it, The Daily Telegraph reported.

headline: Former Fannie and Freddie Regulator Joins W.L. Ross
abstract: James B. Lockhart III, the former head of the regulator that oversaw Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac has joined W.L. Ross & Company as a vice chairman, the distressed investment firm run by Wilbur L. Ross said Wednesday.

headline: How the iTunes Store Can Make Me a Mad Man

headline: Stocks Resume Rally; Dollar at Year’s Low

headline: Signs of an Upswing in Merger Activity

headline: 888, an Online Gambling Company, Says It Is Nearing a Purchase
abstract: An online gambling company, 888, said it was close to making an acquisition after strong trading from its casino, bingo and sports betting Web sites led to an improved overall performance in the second quarter.

headline: At End of Day, Shares Manage to Turn Higher
abstract: Traders hit the pause button on Thursday as they confronted a murky jobs report and reports of weak retail sales, The New York Times’s Jack Healy reported.

headline: Betfair Said to Consider a $2.5 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: Betfair, the gaming exchange, is meeting with advisers to discuss a possible flotation, The Daily Telegraph reported. The flotation is expected to value the group at about $2.5 billion.

headline: The Self-Employed Are Most Satisfied with Their Jobs
abstract: Findings from a new Pew Research Center report can help explain why the self-employed are the happiest workers in America.

headline: Time Warner Will Resist Deal Urge, Analyst Says
abstract: Media moguls are fond of big, splashy deals, many of which fall flat. But analysts at Pali Capital think that Time Warner’s chief executive, Jeff Bewkes, will resist the temptation.

headline: Warner Chilcott to Buy Procter & Gamble Unit
abstract: Warner Chilcott has agreed to buy Procter & Gamble’s prescription drug business, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday.

headline: Great Recession Takes Great Toll on Value of Brand Names
abstract: An annual survey of the value of brand names has found hard times inflicting significant damage to many of them.

headline: China Official Urges Fight on Bank Corruption
abstract: A senior Chinese communist official called for greater efforts to fight corruption in the banking sector, which he qualified as a hotbed.

headline: Judge Delays Trial Over Auction-Rate Securities
abstract: A U.S. judge delayed the trial of a former Credit Suisse Group employee on securities fraud charges to await the arrival Monday of a co-defendant who had fled to Spain, Reuters said.

headline: Wynn Macau I.P.O. Is Said to Raise $1.6 Billion
abstract: The enterprise, run by the gambling mogul Steve Wynn, sold a 25 percent stake in the business.

headline: Low Expectations May Be Helpful for Mideast Talks
abstract: Despite the flurry of diplomatic activity, everyone is tightlipped about exactly where things stand.

headline: Shares Manage to Eke Out a Gain
abstract: The stock market extended its weeklong rally even as it struggled with more worries about the banking industry.

headline: Pitchbook, a Deal Database, Is Said to Land $3.8 Million in Funding
abstract: Pitchbook Data, which operates a subscription-only database of private equity deals and industry players, has raised $3.8 million in funding from angels and an undisclosed strategic investor, PaidContent reported.

headline: Qik Nabs $5.5 Million
abstract: Qik, a start-up that enables live video streaming from a cellphone onto the Internet, has landed $5.5 million in fresh funding.

headline: Barclays Executive to Launch Advice Firm, Report Says
abstract: A high-profile Barclays dealmaker is leaving the British bank to start his own advisory business, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Two Unclaimed Boys
abstract: There is nothing more depressing than seeing a child’s body in a morgue. Correction, there is one thing more depressing. Seeing an unclaimed child’s body in a morgue.

headline: McGraw-Hill Said to Seek Buyer for BusinessWeek
abstract: With business publications suffering from scarce advertising, McGraw-Hill has hired Evercore Partners to sell BusinessWeek, The New York Times reported, but analysts questioned how much interest there would be.

headline: The He-conomy: Do Men Take Too Many Risks?
abstract: Could economic theory, historically dominated by men, possibly overstate the benefits of risk-taking and competition? an economist writes.

headline: Can Mergers Stay Sane?
abstract: Deals are back — at least up to a point. But, Breakingviews wonders, will they stay sensible?

headline: Treasury to Buy Small Business Loans, Report Says
abstract: The Treasury Department is gearing up to launch a $15 billion initiative to stimulate lending by the Small Business Administration by using funds from the federal bailout program to buy up SBA loans, The Washington Post reported.

headline: Q & A: Video Chat Without a Home PC
abstract: Just because you don’t have a computer doesn’t mean you can’t live in the future and have a videophone.

headline: The Afghan Elections: A Postscript
abstract: John Burns tackles more readers questions on Afghanistan.

headline: Designer Tory Burch Sells Minority Stake
abstract: Fashion designer Tory Burch said Friday that she has sold a minority stake in her namesake company to Tresalia Capital, a private equity firm based in Mexico City.

headline: MetLife Set to Combine Some U.S. Businesses
abstract: MetLife, the largest American life insurer, said Tuesday that it planned to combine some United States businesses as part of a revamp it undertook to increase growth opportunities.

headline: Speed Read for July 6, 2009
abstract: Highlights from media coverage in The New York Times:

headline: Geithner Defends Financial Oversight Plan
abstract: Timothy Geithner, the Treasury secretary, urged lawmakers Friday to support the Obama administration’s proposal to overhaul financial regulations.

headline: Pilgrim’s Pride to Sell Majority Stake to JBS
abstract: Pilgrim’s Pride, the poultry producer that filed for bankruptcy protection late last year, said Wednesday it agreed to sell a majority stake of itself to a Brazilian beef producer as part of plan to emerge from Chapter 11.

headline: A Bit Player Emerges in Madoff Affair
abstract: From an innocuous 1988 meeting to flirtation, lunches — along with other afternoon delights — and ultimately betrayal, Sheryl Weinstein recounts her affair with convicted Ponzi schemer Bernard L. Madoff in her new book, “Madoff’s Other Secret: Love, Money, Bernie, and Me.”

headline: For Newspaper Advertising, a Slower Decline
abstract: In the quarter that ends this month, newspaper publishers and analysts are expecting a 25 percent decline in ad revenue year-over-year.

headline: Letterman Is on a Roll, and Conan Posts a ‘Tonight’ Low
abstract: Is David Letterman back? If not all the way, the CBS late-night star certainly seems to be getting there. He scored an impressive win last week in the late-night audience over NBC’s “Tonight Show” with new host Conan O’Brien, as that show suffered through the least-viewed week in “Tonight” history.

headline: From Bits: Xobni Takes the ‘Freemium’ Route
abstract: Xobni, the tool that makes Outlook e-mail a lot easier to use, now offers a paid version.

headline: Germany May Sweeten Opel Aid for Magna Win
abstract: Germany could provide $6.35 billion in state aid for carmaker Opel if General Motors chooses Canada’s Magna, Berlin’s favored suitor, as the buyer, a German minister said.

headline: Cablevision Prices $900 Million Notes Offering
abstract: Cablevision Systems said Wednesday that it had priced a $900 million private placement of debt.

headline: Austrian Banks Said to Be Prepared for Slump
abstract: Austrian banks have enough capital to survive a “drastic” Eastern European recession, the country’s central bank said, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Of Shoes and Happiness
abstract: The Zappos story is inspiring, thought-provoking and impressive. I was hoping for a little math.

headline: Ex-UBS Chief to Advise Buyout Firm
abstract: Marcel Rohner, who left his job as UBS’s chief executive in February, is joining the advisory board of Exigen Capital, a private equity firm, Forbes.com’s Streetwise reported, citing undisclosed sources.

headline: Big Advertisers Agree to Tests of Online Research
abstract: Eight major advertisers, which together spend an estimated $500 million each year on market research, agree to take part in tests to help determine the quality of online research.

headline: Benmosche Said to Target Bankers Fees for I.P.O.s
abstract: American International Group C.E.O. Robert Benmosche would like to trim by half the fees the insurer is paying to Wall Street banks advising it on various I.P.O.s, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google Voice Goes Mobile
abstract: Google Voice is now easier to use in some mobile phones with a new application available on BlackBerry and Android devices.

headline: Fund Investors Said to Demand More Data
abstract: Pension funds, endowments and wealthy investors that have long funneled money into loosely regulated hedge funds will want to see more data detailing how their investments are valued and priced, researchers at State Street found.

headline: How Living Wills Could Help Banks
abstract: To avoid another Lehman Brothers, banks need to start making ”living wills,” contingency plans for safely dismantling themselves if they were to fail in a crisis, Breakingviews says.

headline: Is Starting a Business Brave, Smart, Stupid or Nuts?
abstract: Maybe all of the above. But that’s not the most important question.

headline: Bernanke’s Other Financial Scare
abstract: One year ago, as the nation’s financial system was approaching catastrophe, Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke was having his own personal monetary disturbance.

headline: Madoff Enters North Carolina Prison
abstract: Bernard L. Madoff, the convicted swindler, arrived at a federal prison in Butner, N.C., on Tuesday to start serving a 150-year sentence.

headline: Emmys Do a Little Better
abstract: The revamped Emmy telecast managed to eke out slightly better ratings Sunday night, despite facing the most-watched Sunday night football game ever.

headline: Watchdog Finds S.E.C. Fulfilled Duty in Stanford Case
abstract: The S.E.C. had been investigating the banking business of R. Allen Stanford for more than three years before the Madoff Ponzi scheme came to light in December, and fulfilled its duty to pursue alleged wrongdoing, the agency’s inspector general has found.

headline: Perot Says Cuban Diverted Profits from Arena
abstract: A firm controlled by Ross Perot Jr. has accused Mark Cuban of wrongfully diverting millions of dollars from the Dallas Mavericks’ home arena to help make up for cash shortfalls incurred by the team.

headline: Rising Beer Prices Could Hint at Oligopoly
abstract: Anheuser-Busch InBev and MillerCoors are raising beer prices at the same time. With 80 percent of the market between them, the move almost begs for an antitrust review, Breakingviews.com writes.

headline: Analysts See Upside in Lower Goldman Bonuses
abstract: Goldman Sachs may decide to trim its compensation structure later in the year in a nod to public sentiment, analysts at Pali Capital said. That could be a boon to shareholders.

headline: Twitter Phishers Dangle Bait in Direct Messages
abstract: Twitter is under another phishing attack. This time, the culprits are targeting users through the social network’s private messaging feature.

headline: Letterman to Interview Obama on Monday
abstract: President Obama to appear on David Letterman’s show on Monday night.

headline: Private Equity Firm Seeks Bankruptcy For Wilton
abstract: A private equity firm that holds debt in Wilton Holdings, one of largest makers of equipment for decorating food, asked a court to put the company in Chapter 11 bankruptcy because of its $208 million in debt.

headline: Placemark Picks Up $8 Million
abstract: Placemark Holdings, an investment adviser, has raised $8 million in order to expand its existing business and implement new business plans, The Dallas Business Journal reported.

headline: Other Swiss Banks Expect to Avoid UBS-like Inquiry
abstract: Julius Baer and Credit Suisse executives expect to avoid a U.S. tax investigation into their private banking businesses on the same scale as their peer UBS, they told The Financial Times.

headline: Google Buys Web Video Software Firm
abstract: Google said on Wednesday it agreed to buy On2 Technologies, which sells video compression software, in a stock deal valued at about $106 million.

headline: Amid Investor Wariness, 2 REITs Halve Their I.P.O
abstract: Two private-equity backed real estate investment trusts found themselves cutting their planned initial public offerings by half Wednesday, amid tepid investor response.

headline: Is the A.I.G. Rally a Little Early?
abstract: For American International Group, a return to health looks a long way off — and any investment return to taxpayers is even more distant, Breakingviews says.

headline: Q & A: Big Pain From Small Keyboards
abstract: Ways to expand the keyboard on your tiny, tiny netbook.

headline: Kraft’s Bid for Cadbury Propels European Stocks
abstract: Investors jumped into equities on Monday, sending shares up around the world, while the dollar weakened as demand for riskier assets took hold.

headline: Coming Soon: Lehman Brothers, the Movie
abstract: The BBC said on Wednesday that it is producing “The Last Days of Lehman Brothers,” a TV movie “inspired by the real events” of that September weekend when the storied investment bank fell.

headline: Hoberman Hunting Start-Ups in Europe
abstract: PROfounders co-founder Brent Hoberman is on vacation with a mission: Scouring Europe for the most energetic and disruptive businesses around, The Daily Telegraph reported.

headline: Apple Lifts the Curtain on App Store Approvals
abstract: Apple’s response to the F.C.C. inquiry into the rejection of the Google Voice iPhone app cracked the veneer of the App Store review process.

headline: Balsillie Raises Coyotes Bid by $30 Million
abstract: From Slap Shot: James L. Balsillie, the Canadian billionaire who was already offering $212.5 million to buy the Phoenix Coyotes — some $62 million more than the next-highest bid — increased his offer by another $30 million.

headline: Outspark Closes $8.3 Million Third Round
abstract: Outspark, which runs a “virtual playground” for online gamers, said it closed an $8.3 million venture funding round led by Syncom Venture Partners, a new investor.

headline: Thomson Reuters Closes In on Deal for Breakingviews
abstract: Breakingviews, the financial commentary Web site and a content partner of The New York Times, is in final discussions to sell itself to Thomson Reuters, people briefed on the talks told DealBook on Monday.

headline: Now Hiring at Talking Points Memo
abstract: The political news Web site Talking Points Memo completed a round of investment of $500,000 to $1 million, and is nearly doubling its staff to 20.

headline: CIT in Talks With Regulators Over Liquidity Issues
abstract: CIT Group, the struggling U.S. commercial lender, said it remained in active discussions with regulators on measures to improve its near-term liquidity position.

headline: Repsol Acknowledges Offers for YPF, None Certain
abstract: Repsol YPF, the Spanish oil company, told the S.E.C. that it had received a number of proposals for its Argentine assets, though none of them firm offers, after reports of a bid from CNPC of China.

headline: Sanofi Takes Majority Stake in Indian Vaccine Firm
abstract: The pharmaceutical company Sanofi-Aventis said it had agreed to acquire a controlling stake in the Indian vaccine maker Shantha Biotechnics for an undisclosed amount.

headline: Intel Is Said to Plot an Executive Overhaul
abstract: Pat Gelsinger, who runs Intel’s enterprise business, plans to leave the company, and Sean Maloney, head of sales and marketing, will take on a broader role, according to people briefed on the changes.

headline: White-Collar Crime Prosecutor Joins Fried & Frank
abstract: Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson said Thursday that it had hired William F. Johnson, a prominent white-collar crime prosecutor from the office of the United States attorney.

headline: A Spiritual Guidebook Hollywood-Style, Full of Dish
abstract: A spiritual guide book Hollywood-style, full of dish.

headline: Study Argues C.F.T.C. Missed Oil Speculation
abstract: A new study contends that speculation by financial players like banks, hedge funds and index funds was behind the steep rise in oil prices last year.

headline: Virgin America Said to Seek O.K. for U.S. Investment

headline: What’s The Best Way to Reward Sales People?
abstract: Some companies pay straight commission. Others pay only salary. And many others do some combination. I have been to seminars, talked to consultants, and read articles on the subject. Everyone who has an opinion is sure it’s right.

headline: Everbright Bank Cleared for Private Placement
abstract: China Everbright Bank’s $1.7 billion private share placement has been given a green light by regulatory authorities, furthering the bank’s quest for an initial public offering.

abstract: Plans are being drawn up in Germany to allow banks threatened with bankruptcy to be put into receivership administered by the state, according to the draft of a bill obtained by the daily Sueddeutsche Zeitung.

abstract: The Lloyds Banking Group named Winfried F. W. Bischoff as chairman to succeed Victor Blank, who is retiring, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Sungevity Powers Up With New Funding
abstract: Sungevity, a Web-based solar panel installation company, said Tuesday it raised $6 million in a second financing round led by a new venture firm called Greener Capital.

abstract: DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports live from day two of the General Motors hearing to win approval of its asset sale to a new government-backed company.

headline: Lenovo Parent Plans $1.46 Billion in Investments

abstract: After Goldman Sachs’s day in the sun, Wall Street is turning its eyes to Jamie Dimon and JPMorgan Chase.

abstract: Prime Minister Stephen Harper is showing little inclination to intervene in the sale of Nortel’s prime assets to a foreign buyer, saying he is reluctant to erect protectionist barriers in Canada.

headline: Pay Czar Expects Rulings Will Upset Some Bankers
abstract: Kenneth R. Feinberg joked that he might have to move to Pluto to escape the fallout from his first compensation decisions, which are expected in October.

abstract: Proving that sometimes good reviews do pay off for television shows, the new comedy “Modern Family” opened Wednesday night to very impressive ratings for ABC.

headline: Microsoft Office 2010 Starts Ascension to the Cloud
abstract: Microsoft shows off some of the online bits and bobs coming in Office 2010 as it responds to competitors pushing Internet-based productivity software.

abstract: Michael Schumacher said that neck pain stemming from a motorcycle accident in February had forced him to call off his Formula One comeback.

abstract: The filmmakers behind an itty-bitty romantic comedy called “X’s and O’s” are over the moon that it has been pirated on the Internet.

abstract: Two new Exilim cameras are designed to detect and determine the correct exposure for a nonhuman subject.

abstract: Twitter confirms that it raised a significant round of funding and thanks its new investors.

headline: Vitacost.com Prepares $48 Million I.P.O.

headline: A Year Later, H.P.’s Bet on E.D.S. Looks Like a Winner
abstract: Hewlett-Packard’s acquisition of Electronic Data Systems has been hard on E.D.S., but has paid off big for H.P. — so well, in fact, that an important rival has decided to strike a similar deal.

headline: Bernanke, a Hero to His Own, Can’t Shake Critics
abstract: Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, may have credibility in financial circles, but both he and the Fed have come under fire from lawmakers in both parties over the handling of particular bailouts and the scope of the Fed’s power.

headline: Man Group Says Withdrawals Continue
abstract: Man Group, the world’s biggest listed hedge fund firm, said investors have continued to withdraw their money although private investor sales have picked up.

headline: BusinessWeek, on the Block and Ailing
abstract: Numbers sometimes tell a story. And the figures for BusinessWeek suggest it is having one tough time. McGraw-Hill is seeking a buyer for the magazine.

abstract: Investors pushed stocks up on Wall Street on Thursday after a drop in weekly unemployment claims and an upbeat forecast from Procter & Gamble.

abstract: James S. McDonald, the president and chief executive of Rockefeller & Company, a wealth management firm, died on Sunday in Massachusetts. He was 56.

abstract: Wilbur Ross, the billionaire investor known for investing in troubled industries, said he was looking at potential deals for auto parts businesses, including at least one in Europe.

headline: Venture Capital Still Slow in Bay Area, Report Says
abstract: According to a survey by MoneyTree, venture capital investments in Bay Area start-ups were still slow in the second quarter of 2009. Over all, $1.17 billion came from 174 investments compared to $1.27 billion into 185 deals in the previous quarter.

abstract: I know Neat Receipts is years old, and I probably should have covered it long ago. But people, I’m willing to come right out and say it: this thing has changed my life

abstract: Some employees in General Motors‘s investment management division in New York, where top earners make $2 million to $3 million a year, are coming under scrutiny from the White House pay czar, Kenneth Feinberg.

abstract: Someone hoped that I did not scare anyone out of going into business with my piece. But if this story is all it took to scare someone away, then I did a public service.

abstract: The assault on the microblogging service began about 9 a.m., and many users are still finding the site inaccessible.

abstract: Apax Partners’ $570 million acquisition of Bankrate, the consumer-finance Web site, may become a model for the next generation of private equity deals.

abstract: PROfounders co-founder Brent Hoberman is on vacation with a mission: Scouring Europe for the most energetic and disruptive businesses around, The Daily Telegraph reported.

abstract: From Slap Shot: James L. Balsillie, the Canadian billionaire who was already offering $212.5 million to buy the Phoenix Coyotes — some $62 million more than the next-highest bid — increased his offer by another $30 million.

abstract: U.S. taxpayers will probably never recover all of the hundreds of billions of dollars invested to bail out financial firms, automakers and homeowners, Neil Barofsky, the special inspector general for TARP, said on Thursday.

abstract: Clients with more than $5.5 billion invested in hedge funds controlled by Cerberus Capital Management have told the secretive investment firm, run by Stephen A. Feinberg, that they want their money back.

abstract: The judge weighing Bank of America’s $33 million settlement with the S.E.C. said he remained puzzled by explanations of the agreement — and he is seeking more clarity.

abstract: Saab has exited the Swedish equivalent of Chapter 11 bankruptcy, but the carmaker’s future is still uncertain as Stockholm has refused the idea of a government loan to help wrap up its sale.

headline: Attack on Twitter Came in Two Waves
abstract: The cyberattack that knocked Twitter offline Thursday was the result of a two-pronged attack by enemies of a Georgian blogger, according to a security company that analyzed the assault.

headline: Buying Madoff’s Beach House — an Act of Charity?
abstract: The broker handling the sale of Bernard L. Madoff’s Montauk beach house has a novel pitch to sell the property: In shelling out $8.75 million for the two-story building, the buyer will be committing a charitable act.

headline: GLG Partners Said to Launch Distressed Fund
abstract: GLG Partners is the latest hedge fund to begin a new fund focused on distressed investing, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Citi Names McGuire as Sole Head of Global Banking
abstract: Citigroup named Raymond J. McGuire, one of its most senior deal-makers, as its sole head of global investment banking, amid another management reshuffling at the bank. Read the internal memo on DealBook.

headline: Another View: In Praise of Law Firm Layoffs
abstract: Dan Slater, the former writer of The Wall Street Journal Law Blog, argues that layoffs at law firms are the best thing to happen to the legal industry in years.

headline: Bling Nation Rings in $8 Million
abstract: Bling Nation, which allows users to pay for goods in stores via their cellphone, has landed $8 million in funding, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Investors Retreat as Post-Fed Rally Quickly Fades
abstract: Wall Street got an initial lift on Wednesday from the Federal Reserve’s assessment that an economic recovery was under way, but the glow faded fast, dragging stocks to their second day of losses this week.

headline: Scene From an Afghan Wedding
abstract: Adam B. Ellick attends an Afghan wedding and finds a surreal mix of stoicism and energy.

headline: Google’s Much-Anticipated Wave Opens Up a Bit
abstract: Google expands the availability of Wave, a new communications tool that is one of its most anticipated products of the year.

headline: China Fund May Target U.S. Real Estate, Report Says
abstract: China’s $300 billion sovereign-wealth fund is weighing a move to bet big on distressed U.S. real estate assets, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Candover Shakes Up Management
abstract: Candover Investments, the private equity firm, announced a wholesale shake-up at the top of the firm on Friday, as it looks to repair its damaged reputation and salvage its 2008 fund.

headline: Channel Warns: Don’t Eat This at Home
abstract: Do food shows make you fat? Not the genteel chef vs. chef competitions that are a reality television staple, perhaps. But what about shows that have their hosts tackle extreme gastronomic challenges — like eating a 7 ½-pound Sasquatch hamburger at the Big Foot Lodge in Memphis or an 11-pound pizza, known as the Carnivore, at Big Pie in the Sky in Atlanta? That would be “Man v. Food,” which will begin its second season on the Travel Channel on Aug. 5 at 10 p.m.

headline: Jack Kliger Takes the Remote at TV Guide
abstract: A publishing industry veteran, Jack Kliger, will become acting chief executive of the trying-to-reinvent-itself TV Guide Magazine.

headline: Financiers Have the Apartment Graduation Blues
abstract: Buying high and selling low is not a good motto on Wall Street, but some big names in finance seem willing to sacrifice a few million here or there to the gods of the Fifth Avenue co-op boards.

headline: Hurdles to G.M.’s Sale Plan Fall Away
abstract: A lawyer representing five G.M. accident victims told DealBook that, despite filing an appeal of a judge’s approval of the carmaker’s planned asset sale, he’s not looking to block it.

headline: S.E.C. to Proceed With Trial in BofA Case
abstract: Responding to an order by Judge Jed S. Rakoff, the Securities and Exchange Commission and Bank of America have jointly filed a case management plan outlining the steps they plan to take before heading to trial on Feb. 1, 2010.

headline: Tech’s Biggest Deal-Makers
abstract: Steve Ballmer may have failed in its quest to buy Yahoo, but his company, Microsoft, is no slouch in the deal department. Dealogic looks at the most acquisitive tech companies since 2001.

headline: As Bankers Push Firms to Pay Down Debt, Who Wins?
abstract: Bankers who spent the last few years stuffing companies with debt are now hoping to drain some out. But with the “re-equitization” trend, as with leveraging, bankers may end up doing better than their clients, Breakingviews writes.

headline: Google’s Fast Flip Deal Has a Familiar Ring
abstract: Google’s agreement with some news publishers over its new Fast Flip service resembles other deals that Google has cut with content owners.

headline: A Most Dangerous Profession in Russia
abstract: The Committee to Protect Journalists has published a wide-ranging investigation into the all too frequent tendency of journalists in Russia to turn up dead.

headline: PlayOn Video-Streaming App Comes to the Wii
abstract: A new version of PlayOn will turn a Nintendo Wii into a bridge between your PC’s video and your TV.

headline: Wall Street Ends the Day Mixed
abstract: As markets wavered Wednesday, oil prices fell to their lowest point in six weeks on signs that fuel stockpiles are growing and demand continues to dwindle.

headline: Happy Employer Nation Day!
abstract: You haven’t heard of it either? Well, it’s part of the latest G.O.P. effort to recruit campaign contributors from the ranks of small businesses.

headline: Failing Guaranty Bank Is Sold to BBVA of Spain
abstract: Guaranty Bank, a deeply troubled Texas lender, was sold Friday to Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria of Spain in one of the largest government-assisted deals offered to a foreign bank.

headline: China to Sell Government Yuan Bonds in Hong Kong
abstract: The Chinese Ministry of Finance said Tuesday that it would issue 6 billion yuan worth of government bonds in Hong Kong, a major step to internationalize its currency at a time of concern about the dollar.

headline: Hedge Funds Back in Hiring Mode
abstract: Hedge funds and bank trading desks are hiring again after the downturn and have already snapped up some of the most talented managers dislodged as firms struggled in the credit crisis, Reuters reported.

headline: A Winning Wednesday for Leno and NBC
abstract: Jay Leno bounced back up Wednesday, the third night of his new prime-time hour, adding about 2.5 million viewers from his Tuesday show.

headline: Do as I Say, Not as I Do
abstract: Three weeks after taking a one-third stake in Citigroup’s, the government still hasn’t filed the customary paperwork with regulators. That’s because the rules are different if you’re Uncle Sam.

headline: Chais Accuses Madoff Trustee of Seizing His Money
abstract: The retired money manager, 83, says the trustee froze an account without proving in court that he had the right to take the money.

headline: Mayfield Hires V.C. for Her Fresh Eye
abstract: From Bits: Mayfield Fund said Monday that it has hired a 32-year-old from rival Draper Fisher Jurvetson to focus on Web start-ups with “real” businesses, like e-commerce companies.

headline: Television Icons Reflect on Cronkite’s Career
abstract: A wide range of television icons released statements Friday reflecting on Mr. Cronkite’s contributions to the country.

headline: Madoff Feeder Fund to Pay Millions
abstract: Fairfield Greenwich Advisors, the hedge fund that channeled money to convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff, has agreed to reimburse its Massachusetts investors about $8 million for losses.

headline: Is That an App Recommendation, or an Ad?
abstract: Apple boasts of its new app-recommendation page, but how apps wind up there remains a mystery.

headline: Lexmark Revamps Its Inkjet Printer Line
abstract: Lexmark announces eight new all-in-one inkjet printers.

headline: An Introduction to ‘At War’
abstract: Today, we introduce you to a new blog about America at war, recognizing that war is now, and will be, a defining experience for Americans.

headline: Visual Diary: Qaraqosh’s Finest
abstract: The Iraqi police force remains vulnerable to infiltration and local power struggles.

headline: In San Francisco, Plans to Start News Web Site
abstract: A wealthy investor, a journalism school and a public radio station have joined forces to create a nonprofit local news Web site for the San Francisco area, in what may be the largest and most ambitious of dozens of similar local news operations that have cropped up around the United States.

headline: Lehman Asks to Unseal Documents From Barclays Probe
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings and its unsecured creditors asked a bankruptcy judge Thursday to unseal court documents related to an investigation of the sale of Lehman’s core U.S. assets to Barclays.

headline: An Ill-Timed and Ill-Targeted Stimulus
abstract: Construction data over the last couple of years vividly supports the view that federal spending would never provide much “stimulus,” an economist writes.

headline: UBS Posts $1.3 Billion Quarterly Loss
abstract: UBS posted a $1.3 billion quarterly loss on Tuesday, the third in a row for Switzerland’s biggest bank, and blamed costs linked to its reorganization program.

headline: Legg Mason Makes Management Changes in Funds
abstract: Legg Mason Partners’ Equity Income Builder fund is to be merged into the Legg Mason Partners Capital and Income fund, The Baltimore Business Journal reported.

abstract: Sprint Nextel has agreed to buy Virgin Mobile USA, a prepaid cellphone carrier, and I.B.M. will pay $1.2 billion for analytics software maker SSPS.

abstract: The Chinese are used to encountering resistance from Western governments when they move to buy up Western companies, but now Libya is giving the acquisitive nation a hard time as well.

headline: Ancient Haven of San Marino Fights for Banking Life

headline: JPMorgan May Struggle to Offload Office Space

abstract: Google said on Wednesday it agreed to buy On2 Technologies, which sells video compression software, in a stock deal valued at about $106 million.

headline: Amid Investor Wariness, 2 REITs Halve Their I.P.O
abstract: Two private-equity backed real estate investment trusts found themselves cutting their planned initial public offerings by half Wednesday, amid tepid investor response.

headline: Is the A.I.G. Rally a Little Early?
abstract: For American International Group, a return to health looks a long way off — and any investment return to taxpayers is even more distant, Breakingviews says.

headline: Q & A: Big Pain From Small Keyboards
abstract: Ways to expand the keyboard on your tiny, tiny netbook.

headline: Kraft’s Bid for Cadbury Propels European Stocks

headline: Hoberman Hunting Start-Ups in Europe
abstract: PROfounders co-founder Brent Hoberman is on vacation with a mission: Scouring Europe for the most energetic and disruptive businesses around, The Daily Telegraph reported.

headline: Apple Lifts the Curtain on App Store Approvals
abstract: Apple’s response to the F.C.C. inquiry into the rejection of the Google Voice iPhone app cracked the veneer of the App Store review process.

headline: Balsillie Raises Coyotes Bid by $30 Million
abstract: From Slap Shot: James L. Balsillie, the Canadian billionaire who was already offering $212.5 million to buy the Phoenix Coyotes — some $62 million more than the next-highest bid — increased his offer by another $30 million.

headline: D.E. Shaw to Open in Dubai
abstract: D.E. Shaw. the world’s fourth largest hedge fund, is opening an office in Dubai to tap public and private opportunities in the world’s largest oil exporting region.

headline: Cablevision Spinning Off Some Assets, Report Says
abstract: Cablevision Systems is preparing to spin off its Madison Square Garden assets, Bloomberg News reported Wednesday, citing a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Are Bailouts Part of the Problem?
abstract: Daniel Alpert, managing partner at Westwood Capital, is questioning the government’s strategy in fighting the financial crisis, arguing it has just delayed the inevitable.

headline: An Uptick in New Hedge Funds
abstract: Would-be hedge fund managers who were forced to shelve plans to hang their shingle due to the financial crisis are beginning to test the waters again.

headline: Display Ads Tank, Search Surges
abstract: Advertising will be making a robust comeback on the Web, but the growth will come in search and mobile, with Web display advertising continuing to lag.

abstract: Hackers are now raiding business bank accounts through software that can thwart corporate security systems that create passwords, such as RSA’s SecurID.

abstract: Barrick Gold, the world’s largest gold miner, said Wednesday that it was eyeing global M&A opportunities and would consider assets that include copper.

abstract: Natixis, the French investment bank, requested a suspension of its shares after the business daily Les Echos reported that its parent bank may guarantee its riskiest assets.

abstract: In a surprise move on Monday, Citadel Investment Group canceled plans to sell nearly two-thirds of its equity stake in E*Trade Financial, sending shares in the online retail broker soaring 18 percent.

abstract: In fewer than 45 days each, General Motors and Chrysler swept through government-sponsored sales in bankruptcy court — quick tours that have riveted bankruptcy lawyers and law professors.

abstract: Blackstone has moved to the head of the class in compiling and managing hedge fund portfolios for investors, The New York Post noted, citing Hedge Fund Journal.

abstract: The biggest stakeholder in the parent company of Lenovo said Monday that it was seeking to sell 29 percent of the parent company’s shares for $404 million.

abstract: The agency’s board moved to relax some of its proposed rules while still imposing tough standards on private equity firms seeking to buy troubled financial institutions.

abstract: Stephen G. Pagliuca said that he was seeking the Democratic nomination to run for the seat once held by the Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts.

headline: More on Red States and Blue States

abstract: Newly-released data from PayScale, a site that collects salary data, on the salaries of graduates from different colleges.

abstract: Attendees at this week’s Allen & Company media conference in Sun Valley, Idaho, are likely to be talking about the troubled state of traditional media and the sudden rise of Twitter.

abstract: Wells Fargo has joined other big banks in reporting significant second-quarter results, with a 47 percent rise in profit helped by its acquisition of Wachovia.

headline: The Best Internet Addresses Will Cost a Cool .Million
abstract: Icann will let companies buy entire top level domains, like .pepsi or .ibm. But only companies with $1 million to spend can get these prime addresses.

abstract: A combination of Comcast and Time Warner Cable would yield big benefits for both companies and face fewer challenges than many people think, a Citigroup analyst said.

abstract: AFTRA leaders discuss the state of the entertainment industy.

abstract: An appearance by President Obama lifted David Letterman to his best overnight ratings number in four years and his second-best season-premiere number since he started on CBS in 1993.

abstract: The venture capitalists who have been calling for investment to shrink by half are practicing what they preach.

abstract: Citadel Investment Group will return millions to clients who asked to exit last year, but were locked in when its flagship funds lost more than half their value during the financial crisis.

abstract: Google said on Wednesday it agreed to buy On2 Technologies, which sells video compression software, in a stock deal valued at about $106 million.

abstract: Two private-equity backed real estate investment trusts found themselves cutting their planned initial public offerings by half Wednesday, amid tepid investor response.

abstract: For American International Group, a return to health looks a long way off — and any investment return to taxpayers is even more distant, Breakingviews says.

abstract: Ways to expand the keyboard on your tiny, tiny netbook.

abstract: PROfounders co-founder Brent Hoberman is on vacation with a mission: Scouring Europe for the most energetic and disruptive businesses around, The Daily Telegraph reported.

abstract: From Slap Shot: James L. Balsillie, the Canadian billionaire who was already offering $212.5 million to buy the Phoenix Coyotes — some $62 million more than the next-highest bid — increased his offer by another $30 million.

abstract: Fresh from its acquisition of Gleacher Partners, Broadpoint Gleacher Securities is expanding into the real estate investment banking business.

abstract: Comic-Con: Hollywood’s wagging tongues begin to debate James Cameron’s “Avatar.”

abstract: Bank of America said Monday that it hired Sallie Krawcheck, who was most recently the head of global wealth management at archrival Citigroup, as head of its global wealth and investment management business as part of a series of high-level management shifts at the bank.

abstract: “Two and twenty” — three words that long held the key to transforming fledgling hedge fund managers into instant tycoons — may be due for a pruning.

abstract: Dell’s latest laptop is dressed to impress with a black cherry finish, thin as a socialite, instant-on e-mail and just about wirelesss everything including power.

abstract: The Tribune Company could well emerge from bankruptcy this fall with much of its current top management intact, but it remains unclear whether that might include the top dog himself, Samuel Zell.

abstract: PBM Products, a maker of private-label baby foods, is seeking to arrange for a buyout or partial sale of the company with food manufacturers and private equity firms showing interest, The Wall Street Journal said.

abstract: Doubt has been cast on a report that the hedge fund Paulson & Company wants to combine the struggling lender the CIT Group with a Paulson-affiliated bank once known as IndyMac.

headline: Bernie’s Dictators

abstract: Media barons, bankers and tech entrepreneurs are in Sun Valley, Idaho, for this week’s media and technology conference. DealBook has a slide show.

headline: UBS to Disclose Over 4,000 Client Names

headline: Ex-Partner at Tax Firm Pleads Guilty in Shelter Case
abstract: A former partner at BDO Seidman pleaded guilty in federal court Thursday to three counts of conspiracy in connection with tax shelter transactions.

abstract: Citigroup intends to sell off noncore assets in order to tighten its focus and shore up its balance sheet.

headline: What Should Be Done?
abstract: Is there a way to stop high-frequency traders from gaming the market?

abstract: Cadbury may have rebuffed Kraft’s $16.7 billion bid, but Kraft’s chief executive, Irene B. Rosenfeld, appears determined to push the deal forward, and a look at her past shows she has the determination to follow through.

headline: U.S. Lobbies E.U. to Soften Fund Rules, Report Says

headline: Q & A: Securing a Mac Flash Drive

abstract: Venture capitalists want the industry to shrink and have been calling for fewer funds to raise less money. Now there is more data that shows that is happening, Claire Cain Miller writes for Bits.

abstract: Most lists of the top-earning films of all time do not take into account inflation.

abstract: From Slap Shot: James L. Balsillie, the Canadian billionaire who was already offering $212.5 million to buy the Phoenix Coyotes — some $62 million more than the next-highest bid — increased his offer by another $30 million.

abstract: Amazon, the leading online retailer, is acquiring an online shoe retailer that is famous for its obsession with customer service.
