headline: Life After UBS: Costas’s New Boutique
abstract: John P. Costas, the former head of UBS’s investment banking unit, is back in business with a new investment banking boutique called PrinceRidge. He left the firm after the hedge fund unit he ran was shut down two years ago.

headline: Largest Carmaker in Russia May Lay Off 27,000
abstract: Executives at Avtovaz, the largest Russian carmaker, are reportedly considering laying off about 27,000 employees to improve performance at a factory that has been clobbered by the sharp drop in demand for cars.

headline: AT&T Says F.C.C. Neutrality Suggests a ‘Bait and Switch’
abstract: While other wireless companies waffled, AT&T said it wasn’t fair for the F.C.C. to impose new network neutrality rules on wireless networks after auctioning off spectrum with no such restrictions.

headline: Trump Entertainment Sued Over Failed Hotel Deal
abstract: Trump Entertainment Resorts is being sued for $17 million by a company that once intended to buy the Trump Marina Hotel.

headline: Class Size Around the World
abstract: America’s classrooms have slightly more students than the classrooms in most other developed countries — but not by much.

headline: Apple Rehires a Developer of Its Newton Tablet
abstract: Michael Tchao, one of the key figures behind Apple’s Newton tablet computer, has returned to the company after 15 years.

headline: As JAL Seeks to Survive, U.S. Rivals Vie for a Stake
abstract: A last-ditch attempt by the biggest airline in Japan to raise money and avoid bankruptcy has set the stage for a battle between two U.S. titans, Delta and American Airlines.

headline: Emmy Awards Show Will Be Pruned
abstract: The Emmy Awards ceremony is getting a makeover, and a lot of people in Hollywood are not happy about it.

headline: Congress to Weigh Google Books Settlement
abstract: Opponents and supporters of the settlement will square off in a Congressional hearing on Thursday.

headline: Oaktree Said to Seek Japan REIT Merger
abstract: Oaktree Capital Management may merge its Japanese real estate trust with others in the country, Robert Zulkoski, head of the special situations and real estate team in Asia, told Bloomberg News.

headline: Samsung-Bosch Venture Buys U.S. Battery Maker
abstract: SB LiMotive, an electric vehicle battery joint venture between Samsung SDI and Robert Bosch, is buying the United States battery maker Cobasys.

headline: BNP Paribas Pulling Out of Listed Tax Havens
abstract: BNP Paribas, the biggest French bank, is to close subsidiaries located in countries on the OECD’s “grey list” of nations which have not fully implemented global tax standards.

headline: Life After Lehman: Wall Street Workers Move On
abstract: Tom Ollquist remembers Sept. 9, 2008 — the day Lehman Brothers laid him off — as if it were yesterday. “You’re not going to believe it,” he told his wife. “I was shot.” Six days later, so was Lehman Brothers.

headline: A Day of Wandering Ends Lower on Wall Street
abstract: Stocks wandered lower on Tuesday as investors balanced an improvement in housing prices against a decline in consumer confidence — indicators that painted a muddled picture of the economic recovery.

headline: Nikon Announces Four New Coolpix Models
abstract: OLED screens, built-in projectors and other new features appear in Nikon’s latest line of cameras.

headline: LyondellBasell Offers a Deal to Soothe Senior Creditors
abstract: After taking a walloping in the wake of bankruptcies, senior creditors finally get a small win, in a stock deal being offered by LyondellBasell, Breakingviews.com says.

headline: Ticketmaster and Live Nation Merger Raises Concerns
abstract: U.S. lawmakers are warning that the proposed merger of Ticketmaster Entertainment and concert promoter Live Nation raises competition concerns and deserves antitrust scrutiny.

headline: Epson Printers Fuse Function and Design
abstract: Epson adds two new all-in-one printers that combine performance with attractive design.

headline: ‘Terminator’ Producers Sue Hedge Fund Backer
abstract: “Terminator Salvation,” one of the most expensive independent film productions ever, on Monday became embroiled in a legal fight between two of the film’s producers and a hedge fund that provided $30 million to purchase rights to the “Terminator” series.

headline: Terms Emerge for New Delphi Deal; Auction Set for Tuesday
abstract: Delphi’s new deal to emerge from bankruptcy, struck with its lenders and onetime parent General Motors, is similar in many ways to its previous agreement with Platinum Equity, The New York Times reported Friday.

headline: Judge Approves $40 Million Eclipse Purchase
abstract: A federal bankruptcy judge on Thursday approved a $40 million offer to purchase Eclipse Aviation, giving the Albuquerque-based manufacturer a chance to restart production of its light jet.

headline: Q&A: Giving Linux a Bit of Audacity
abstract: How to install audio-editing software Audacity on a Linux machine.

headline: Where Politics Don’t Belong
abstract: For years now, many businesses and individuals in the United States have been relying on the power of government, rather than competition in the marketplace, to increase their wealth, and the trend is accelerating.

headline: The Divided States of America
abstract: “There is not a black America and a white America and Latino America and Asian America,” Barack Obama said in 2004. But a new survey shows Americans still perceive strong social conflicts between different groups.

headline: Google Buys Web Video Software Firm
abstract: Google said on Wednesday it agreed to buy On2 Technologies, which sells video compression software, in a stock deal valued at about $106 million.

headline: Who Is the Small Business Majority?
abstract: The organization has gotten a lot of press this spring, first as one of two small business invitees to the White House health care summit in March. But just what is Small Business Majority, and whom does it really represent?

headline: Amid Investor Wariness, 2 REITs Halve Their I.P.O
abstract: Two private-equity backed real estate investment trusts found themselves cutting their planned initial public offerings by half Wednesday, amid tepid investor response.

headline: Is the A.I.G. Rally a Little Early?
abstract: For American International Group, a return to health looks a long way off — and any investment return to taxpayers is even more distant, Breakingviews says.

headline: Q & A: Big Pain From Small Keyboards
abstract: Ways to expand the keyboard on your tiny, tiny netbook.

headline: Kraft’s Bid for Cadbury Propels European Stocks
abstract: Investors jumped into equities on Monday, sending shares up around the world, while the dollar weakened as demand for riskier assets took hold.

headline: Coming Soon: Lehman Brothers, the Movie
abstract: The BBC said on Wednesday that it is producing “The Last Days of Lehman Brothers,” a TV movie “inspired by the real events” of that September weekend when the storied investment bank fell.

headline: Hoberman Hunting Start-Ups in Europe
abstract: PROfounders co-founder Brent Hoberman is on vacation with a mission: Scouring Europe for the most energetic and disruptive businesses around, The Daily Telegraph reported.

headline: Apple Lifts the Curtain on App Store Approvals
abstract: Apple’s response to the F.C.C. inquiry into the rejection of the Google Voice iPhone app cracked the veneer of the App Store review process.

headline: Balsillie Raises Coyotes Bid by $30 Million
abstract: From Slap Shot: James L. Balsillie, the Canadian billionaire who was already offering $212.5 million to buy the Phoenix Coyotes — some $62 million more than the next-highest bid — increased his offer by another $30 million.

headline: An iPhone App for Buying the Latest Fashions
abstract: Net-a-Porter.com, a high-end online fashion retailer, introduces an iPhone app that lets women buy luxury clothes from their iPhones.

headline: Venezuela ‘Democratizes’ Airwaves, Hits the Off Button on 34 Stations
abstract: Opposition radio stations face closure in Venezuela.

headline: Down Rounds Predominate in V.C., Survey Finds
abstract: Turning up the heat on entrepreneurs, venture capitalists have taken to taking up much larger chunks of ownership of companies in return for investments, VentureBeat reported, thus pushing their values down.

headline: For Hyatt, the Timing Is Good for an I.P.O.
abstract: The Pritzker family seems to have picked an odd time to hold an initial public offering for Hyatt Hotels, but they may be right to buck conventional wisdom, Breakingviews writes.

headline: Ghosts on the Front
abstract: Soldiers believe in ghosts.

headline: Behind the Deal: Bankrate
abstract: The Deal Professor thought that Bankrate’s take-private transaction might be a model for future buyouts. But after seeing recent filings, he’s changed his mind.

headline: Toyota Chief Tries a New Ride in U.S. Tour
abstract: Akio Toyoda was originally supposed to hop a Lexus to his hotel during this week’s visit to Michigan. But the new president of Toyota changed that plan when a different car caught his eye.

headline: Sinopec Completes China’s Biggest Foreign Takeover
abstract: Sinopec Group said it completed its $7.5 billion acquisition of Addax Petroleum, obtaining new reserves in Africa and the Middle East in China’s biggest foreign corporate takeover to date.

headline: Bankruptcy Judge to Expedite Review of Cubs Sale
abstract: A judge presiding over Tribune Co.’s bankruptcy case has agreed to expedited procedures regarding the company’s sale of the Chicago Cubs baseball team.

headline: Imagining a Profitable YouTube
abstract: Google says that YouTube, which it bought three years ago, will eventually reach profitability. The San Francisco Chronicle looks at what steps Google is taking to get there.

headline: National Australia Bank Raises $1.6 Billion
abstract: National Australia Bank, the country’s largest lender by assets, said it had raised $1.6 billion by selling shares at a discount in a move to strengthen its balance sheet, The Associated Press reported.

headline: More on Entrepreneurial Youth
abstract: Is there a correlation between interest in entrepreneurship and the performance of the economy?

headline: F.D.I.C. Rules May Hinder Bank Buyouts
abstract: The F.D.I.C. issued preliminary guidelines that analysts said could stymie further plans by private equity firms and hedge funds to purchase failed banks.

headline: TomTom Attracts Buyers for Rights Offer
abstract: The Dutch navigation device maker TomTom attracted a 96 percent take-up for its share offer of 4.21 euros per share and said it placed a rump offering at 5.70 euros per share.

headline: UBS Hires JPMorgan Real Estate Team in Australia
abstract: In Australia, UBS has moved quickly to replace its real estate investment team by picking up Tim Church and seven colleagues from JPMorgan.

headline: Areva Said to Receive 3 Bids on Transmission Unit
abstract: Areva SA, the biggest builder of nuclear reactors, received three offers of less than 4 billion euros ($5.9 billion) for its transmission and distribution unit, three people familiar with the sale told Bloomberg News.

headline: Will Antitrust Probe Keep Microsoft, Yahoo Apart?
abstract: Yahoo and Microsoft hope that by teaming up, they can tilt the balance of power away from Google. First, however, Yahoo and Microsoft have to convince regulators that their plan won’t hurt advertisers and consumers.

headline: Tablet Computers Are Coming Soon, Nvidia Says
abstract: Nvidia says several customers are developing tablet computers that use its Tegra chip. The devices, which are being tested now, should be on sale by early next year.

headline: Music Blog Network Raises $5 Million
abstract: MOG, the music blogging network, has raised $5 million in fresh funding in a round led by Menlo Ventures, VentureBeat reported.

headline: UBS Names Heads of Investment Banking

headline: The Official A.R.C. Outcry Begins
abstract: A senator takes on the banks, the S.B.A. — and the legislation he backed.

headline: F1 Mid-Summer Movements
abstract: So Max Mosley has again said he will not run for president of the FIA, and Jean Todt will, and Mosley will support Todt. Okay. I believe it this time. The first time Mosley said he was quitting the presidency, a few years ago, I believed it. Turned out he wasn’t. So naturally, when he announced he was quitting last month, I didn’t really believe it, and I said so on this blog. I was right (the next day). But it looks as if this third time is the real one. Still, I cannot help feeling that I’m being naive. But I’ll just put that feeling behind the stronger one that Mosley may really stick to his word this time. What strengthens that thought is that Todt has announced he is running for the presidency, and Todt is not the kind to change his mind or to announce that kind of thing without being serious about it.

headline: Lessons for the S.E.C. From the Madoff Debacle
abstract: After reading Friday’s full report on how the Securities and Exchange Commission missed the Madoff fraud, Peter Henning, a law professor who once worked in the commission’s enforcement division, drew up a list of lessons from the debacle.

headline: Bankers in Europe Criticize Crackdown on Bonuses

headline: Lewis Gets Faint Praise From Buffett
abstract: So what kind of financial leader is Kenneth D. Lewis, Bank of America’s chief executive? The billionaire Warren E. Buffett thinks he is an “ironic hero” who “inadvertently saved” the financial system by hastily moving to buy Merrill Lynch at almost any price.

abstract: Volkswagen will pay about $4.7 billion for a 42 percent stake in Porsche‘s automotive unit as part of the two carmakers’ gradual merger.

abstract: Kraft must make a takeover offer for Cadbury, the chocolate retailer, by Nov. 9 or walk away for six months, the British takeover panel said.

abstract: Cox Enterprises has dropped plans to sell one of its marquee newspapers, the Austin American-Statesman, after failing to get offers as high as it had hoped.

abstract: In its season debut, “NCIS” is a smash hit, drawing more than 20 million viewers.

headline: Greed Is Bad, Gekko. So Is a Meltdown.
abstract: In his sequel to “Wall Street,” the 1987 film that became emblematic of an era of excess, Oliver Stone is looking to capture greed on celluloid all over again, this time set against the backdrop of the financial collapse that began with the fall of Bear Stearns.

abstract: More answers to readers’ questions about financing their continuing educations and determining which program will put them on track to an in-demand career.

abstract: It’s hardly the stuff of sweet New York summer Saturdays by the rowboat lake, but David Ippolito, the barefoot troubadour known simply as “that guitar man from Central Park,” has a new song going national, a cri de coeur against the nation’s interrogation policies growing out of the Iraq war.

headline: SAP Looks to Buy SAF, the Swiss Software Firm
abstract: The German software giant SAP said that it had made an offer of $16.29 per share for SAF Simulation, Analysis & Forecasting, a Swiss provider of forecasting and ordering software.

abstract: In what Citigroup chief executive Vikram Pandit called a “milestone,” the U.S. government will take a 34 percent stake in the banking group. The announcement comes following Sunday’s completion of a $58 billion share offering, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Apple Updates iTunes to Shut Out Palm Pre
abstract: Apple’s newest update to iTunes disables the Palm Pre’s ability to mimic an iPod. But there are workarounds for Pre users.

headline: Dewey Hires 3 Senior Lawyers From Cooley
abstract: Dewey & LeBoeuf has hired away three senior technology lawyers from Cooley Godward Kronish, including one of the Silicon Valley firm’s top deal-makers, Richard E. Climan.

headline: MooBella Lands $18 Million for Ice Cream Machine
abstract: MooBella, a Taunton, Mass.-based company that is gearing up to market a “make-your-own” ice cream machine, said that it has secured $18 million in Series A funding from W. Health LP, a venture fund managed by Inventages.

headline: Look This Up on Wikipedia: How Big Is Too Big?
abstract: Scholars are beginning to question the continued growth of Wikipedia and the implications of its size and structure.

headline: EconoQuiz
abstract: Our regular quiz on economics issues in the news.

headline: An Open Letter to Video-on-Demand Services
abstract: Video-on-demand services from Amazon, Netflix and others are on the Internet, but they’re nowhere close to harnessing the power of the Web.

headline: Congo: Rights Group Reports Attacks on Civilians
abstract: Human Rights Watch said Thursday that recent military operations in the Congo “have been a disaster for civilians, who are now being attacked from all sides.”

headline: Tip of the Week: Turning Off Microsoft Tips
abstract: Although they’re meant to be helpful, Microsoft Word 2007’s ScreenTips can also get in the way.

headline: Marrying iTunes and BlackBerrys
abstract: Can I play music from my PC’s iTunes library on my BlackBerry?

headline: French President Hospitalized
abstract: President Nicolas Sarkozy was taken to a hospital for tests after getting sick while jogging, the government said. Press reports said his health was not in serious danger.

headline: Pakistan: Ruling by Supreme Court on Musharraf Is Expected
abstract: The Supreme Court is expected to rule Friday on a petition regarding whether the imposition of emergency rule by former President Pervez Musharraf in November 2007 was constitutional.

headline: Turkey: 2nd Coup Trial Opens
abstract: The second mass trial of secularists charged with plotting to topple the religiously conservative government began Monday, with two retired generals among the 56 defendants. Prosecutors accuse the defendants of associating with the ultranationalist group Ergenekon. The first trial, with 86 defendants, opened in October.

headline: Italy: Premier Denies Accusations
abstract: A leading Italian news magazine and a leading newspaper published audio tapes and transcripts on Monday of what they said were suggestive conversations between Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi and an escort who has said she was paid to attend parties at his official residence. Mr. Berlusconi has said he did not know the woman was an escort. Mr. Berlusconi’s lawyer, Nicolò Ghedini, questioned the authenticity of the tapes, and said he would evaluate whether to take legal action against the publications, La Repubblica and L’Espresso, the ANSA news agency reported.

headline: Peru: Shining Path Shoots Down Copter
abstract: Guerrillas from a faction of the Shining Path terrorist group on Wednesday shot down an MI-17 helicopter operated by Peru's Air Force in the country's main coca-growing region, killing three members of the military and wounding five, according to Peru's joint command. The crew was on a mission to rescue soldiers wounded in an earlier attack by the rebels. Violence in the remote area, the Apurímac and Ene River Valley, has flared since the army began an operation in August seeking the capture of Jorge Quispe Palomino, a leader of the faction, which has financed its activities from Peru's cocaine trade.

headline: El Salvador: Chronicler of Gangs Slain
abstract: A French-Spanish filmmaker who chronicled the lives of Salvadoran gang members in a new documentary was fatally shot outside San Salvador on Wednesday, the police said. The filmmaker, Christian Poveda, 54, spent more than a year living among the Mara 18 gang to make his documentary, "La Vida Loca," which has been shown in Europe and Mexico. Mr. Poveda was returning from filming in La Campanera, a poor suburb of the capital that is a stronghold of the gang, when he was killed. President Mauricio Funes, a former television journalist himself, said he was dismayed by the murder.

headline: A New Signer for an iPhone
abstract: E-mail messages sent from my iPhone have always been stamped with a line that says “Sent from my iPhone.” Can I change this or get rid of it?

headline: Tip of the Week: Hulu for Your Desktop
abstract: If you watch a lot of television on Hulu.com and want to make it more like a media player and less of a Web browser experience, consider Hulu Desktop.

headline: Earnings Climb Nearly 8% at Yahoo
abstract: Although revenue fell 13 percent, cost-cutting measures helped the company beat analysts’ predictions.

headline: Finn Caspersen, Supporter of Many Causes, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Caspersen, a former chairman and chief executive of the Beneficial Corporation, was a major philanthropist and political donor in New Jersey politics.

headline: S.E.C. Rule Curtailing Short Sales Will Stay
abstract: Federal regulators are making permanent an emergency rule aimed at reducing abusive short-selling, put in at the height of last fall’s market turmoil.

headline: North Korea Asserts New Willingness to Talk
abstract: North Korea said it was open to a form of dialogue to help resolve the dispute with the United States over its nuclear weapons program _ but not to six-nation talks.

headline: British Airways Will Fly Business-Only to New York
abstract: The airline, which had long emphasized its first- and business-class service, may eliminate some short-haul flights to restore earnings.

headline: U.S. to Hunt Down Afghan Drug Lords Tied to Taliban
abstract: U.S. commanders say the addition of drug traffickers to a “kill or capture” list is legal and a key part of a plan to disrupt the flow of drug money to the Taliban.

headline: A New Enforcer in Buildings, the Energy Inspector
abstract: Building inefficient homes locks in waste for decades, but construction codes for many states and cities are weak.

headline: Donald Marshall Jr., Symbol of Bias, Dies at 55
abstract: A wrongful conviction revealed systemic racism against Indians in Canada and became a landmark case.

headline: A Debate Rages in Iceland: Independence vs. I.M.F. Cash
abstract: The island nation is locked in a fierce debate over how to pay off its creditors without ceding too much of its vaunted independence.

headline: Radical Islamists Slip Easily Into Kenya
abstract: The Shabab, a militia that has taken over much of southern Somalia, is considered a threat to Westerners living in Kenya.

headline: In West Bank Settlements, Sign of Hope for a Deal
abstract: Two growing ultra-Orthodox settlements offer the surprising potential for Israeli compromise with the Palestinians.

headline: As Vote Count Gives Karzai a Majority, a Recount Is Ordered

headline: Britain Asks Allies for Help on Employees Held in Iran

headline: Corrections

abstract: Roger Jenkins, who helped the bank avoid a government bailout by winning Middle East investments, will start his own firm.

headline: That’s a Lot of Hot Dogs
abstract: A hot dog vendor is given the boot after failing to pay his $53,558 monthly rent. How many hot dogs would he have to sell to afford his annual payments?

headline: As Home Sales Rise, Has the Economy Reached Its Ebb?
abstract: For the first time since 2005, a year-over-year gain in sales of both used homes and used condos.

headline: What Are We Fighting Over When We Fight Over Money?
abstract: New research has shown that tightwads and spendthrifts tend to marry, and then fight over finances. But are they fighting about spending in general, or spending priorities?

headline: Answering Your Questions About Continuing Education
abstract: Tara Siegel Bernard and Catherine Rampell answer readers’ questions about financing their continuing educations, and how to find programs that put them on a good career path.

headline: Is America’s Small-Business Sector So Small Because of Health Care?
abstract: A follow-up to our post on Wednesday on a report showing America’s small-business sector to be much smaller than that in most industrialized countries.

headline: School’s Out for Summer: A Gem in the Jobs Report
abstract: Hidden in the latest jobs report is a rise in employment among young people that contradicts much of what has been claimed about the labor market, an economist writes.

headline: End-of-Life Care: Where Ethics Meet Economics
abstract: An economist explains some of the tough questions societies face on end-of-life care, decisions, and why the so-called “death panels” don’t address them.

headline: Consumers Aren’t Spending
abstract: The Fed thinks consumer spending is stabilizing. The retail sales figures tell a different story.

headline: Answering Your Questions on Continuing Education, Part II
abstract: As a follow-up to today’s special section on continuing education, more answers to reader questions about financing training and choosing a new career.

headline: Overhauling Social Security on the Agenda, Summers Says
abstract: Lawrence Summers, director of the White House National Economic Council, told a conference of economists that President Obama would probably start addressing the needs of Social Security before the end of his term.

headline: Not Much ‘Sharing’ Here
abstract: Here’s a deal: Get paid $3.5 billion in cash, in return for assuming maximum losses on dubious assets of $1.5 billion. That is the deal BB&T was able to get from the F.D.I.C. in return for taking over Colonial Bank.

headline: Is China Hiding Its Purchases of Treasuries?
abstract: Is China buying bonds through street names in Britain?

headline: A New Member of Club Wagner
abstract: Olivier Blanchard, chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Assorted Links
abstract: The Michael Vick tax credit, and more.

headline: Save This Store
abstract: Why Wall Streeters need those jillion-dollar bonuses.

headline: More on the Summer Jobs Surge
abstract: An economist looks for lessons in the fact that many teenagers entered the job market this summer — and then found jobs.

headline: The Two-Track Economy: Inequality Emerging From Today’s Recession
abstract: Out of the recession, an economist argues, a two-track economy may emerge: one bouncing back in a relatively healthy fashion, and the other, populated by low-income Americans, really struggling.

headline: Another Sign of Recovery?
abstract: Are those animated, dancing ads from LowerMyBills.com — once ubiquitous during the credit bubble — making a comeback?

headline: How Big Are the Environmental Benefits of High-Speed Rail?
abstract: The environmental and mortality benefits of rail are real, but the social benefits from switching from other modes of travel are quite small relative to the system’s cost, an economist writes.

headline: Apple App Store Crosses Another Threshold
abstract: Apple says customers have downloaded two billion applications for the iPhone and iPod Touch.

abstract: Richard Stallman, a free-software activist, says the Spanish-language version of Wikipedia is biased against left-wing causes.

abstract: Wendy Williams to drop her radio program.

headline: ING Swings Back to Profit on Insurance Unit
abstract: After three losing quarters, ING Groep said Wednesday that it had swung back to a small profit for the first time in a year. But earnings at the Dutch bank and insurance giant came in below market expectations because of rising loan-loss provisions and continued write-downs in real estate.

headline: Fed Considers Sweeping Limits on Bank Pay
abstract: The Federal Reserve is preparing what would be the most sweeping rules yet to regulate the pay at banks across the country, people close to the discussion said Friday.

headline: Google Buys Web Video Software Firm
abstract: Google said on Wednesday it agreed to buy On2 Technologies, which sells video compression software, in a stock deal valued at about $106 million.

headline: Who Is the Small Business Majority?
abstract: The organization has gotten a lot of press this spring, first as one of two small business invitees to the White House health care summit in March. But just what is Small Business Majority, and whom does it really represent?

headline: Amid Investor Wariness, 2 REITs Halve Their I.P.O
abstract: Two private-equity backed real estate investment trusts found themselves cutting their planned initial public offerings by half Wednesday, amid tepid investor response.

headline: Is the A.I.G. Rally a Little Early?
abstract: For American International Group, a return to health looks a long way off — and any investment return to taxpayers is even more distant, Breakingviews says.

headline: Q & A: Big Pain From Small Keyboards
abstract: Ways to expand the keyboard on your tiny, tiny netbook.

headline: Kraft’s Bid for Cadbury Propels European Stocks
abstract: Investors jumped into equities on Monday, sending shares up around the world, while the dollar weakened as demand for riskier assets took hold.

headline: Coming Soon: Lehman Brothers, the Movie
abstract: The BBC said on Wednesday that it is producing “The Last Days of Lehman Brothers,” a TV movie “inspired by the real events” of that September weekend when the storied investment bank fell.

headline: Hoberman Hunting Start-Ups in Europe
abstract: PROfounders co-founder Brent Hoberman is on vacation with a mission: Scouring Europe for the most energetic and disruptive businesses around, The Daily Telegraph reported.

headline: Apple Lifts the Curtain on App Store Approvals
abstract: Apple’s response to the F.C.C. inquiry into the rejection of the Google Voice iPhone app cracked the veneer of the App Store review process.

headline: Balsillie Raises Coyotes Bid by $30 Million
abstract: From Slap Shot: James L. Balsillie, the Canadian billionaire who was already offering $212.5 million to buy the Phoenix Coyotes — some $62 million more than the next-highest bid — increased his offer by another $30 million.

headline: Chinese Firm Drops Plan to Buy Lynas
abstract: A Chinese company has abandoned plans to take control of the rare-earths explorer Lynas Corporation after Australian regulators demanded it reduce the scope of the planned transaction.

headline: In Denver, a Different Kind of News Site
abstract: For the second time since The Rocky Mountain News folded in February, a group of Rocky alums has started a news Web site, hoping to mitigate the decline in jobs and competition in Denver journalism.

headline: Why Did Workplace Deaths Decline in 2008?
abstract: And other statistics from the government’s latest data on fatal workplace injuries.

headline: New Zune Joins the Chase with OLED
abstract: Another new Zune arrives next month, this one with features that make it far more competitive with another music player–you know the one.

headline: California I.O.U.’s Add to Bondholders’ Worries
abstract: California prepared to issue i.o.u.’s to pay its bills, a move that raises questions about its ability to make timely payments on the billions of dollars in state bonds now outstanding.

headline: Vuclip Rounds Up $6 Million
abstract: Vuclip, which allows customers to browse and play videos on their mobile phones, has landed $6 million in a second round of funding led by Jafco Ventures.

headline: Court Tells Ruth Madoff to Report Monthly Expenses
abstract: Bernard L. Madoff’s wife, Ruth, must tell a trustee any time she spends $100 on herself, a bankruptcy judge has ruled.

abstract: The British government said Wednesday it plans to tighten up how it supervises banks, scrutinize bonuses paid to their employees and punish misconduct harder as it tries to prevent a re-run of the credit crunch.

abstract: Christine Lagarde, the French finance minister, urged industrialized nations to go further to put an end to excessive guaranteed bonus payouts, saying they provide an incentive for taking on too much risk.

abstract: The founders of Gizmodo and Engadget have a new site for tech lovers.

headline: NYSE Euronext Pays 95% Premium to Buy Nyfix
abstract: NYSE Euronext said it has inked a deal to buy Nyfix, an electronic brokerage that provides trading systems to its New York Stock Exchange, in an all-cash deal worth about $144 million.

headline: Kraft Plays Down Talk of Higher Bid for Cadbury
abstract: Kraft Foods played down speculation that it would be prepared to raise its offer for Cadbury, while Bloomberg News reported that the company was in talks to arrange about $8 billion of financing for the bid.

headline: Who Are the Taliban?
abstract: “We have to think differently about the Taliban,” said one officer. “It’s like they’re selling franchise rights.

headline: Ex-Credit Suisse Broker Captured in Fraud Case
abstract: Julian Tzolov, a former Wall Street broker who became a fugitive after being charged in a securities fraud case has been captured in Spain, U.S. authorities said Wednesday.

abstract: Golden Gate Capital has finalized its acquisition of assets of the troubled retailer Eddie Bauer for $286 million in cash.

headline: News of F1 Races to Come
abstract: The 2010 F1 race schedule and an evening race in Abu Dhabi.

abstract: A hedge fund manager charged with wire fraud and money laundering in a $3.5 billion Ponzi scheme was granted $1.5 million bail and required to wear an electronic monitor, a federal judge in Minnesota ruled.

abstract: The Washington Post wants some impulse control from staff Tweeters.

abstract: Capital Southwest has pumped $6.2 million into Web-hosting firm iMemories in a second round of funding.

abstract: Sinochem, the Chinese state-owned chemical firm, bid $2.5 billion on Monday for the Australian farm chemicals group Nufarm.

abstract: Why is membership in the organization declining and what does this say about its lobbying efforts?

headline: Toshiba Announces World’s Largest SD Card

headline: Does Cerberus (Finally) Have a Hit With Talecris?

The private equity firm named after the mythical three-headed canine that guards the gates of hell took huge losses on high-profile investments in Chrysler and GMAC. But its more boring buyout of the pharmaceutical company Talecris Biotherapeutics looks to be a hit.

The release of nearly 600 pages of correspondence between journalists and the governor’s office this week opened a rare window onto the tactics networks use to secure high-profile interviews with scandal-plagued newsmakers.

abstract: Golden Gate Capital has won the bankruptcy auction for Eddie Bauer, the seller of outdoorsy clothing, with a $286 million bid.

abstract: PROfounders co-founder Brent Hoberman is on vacation with a mission: Scouring Europe for the most energetic and disruptive businesses around, The Daily Telegraph reported.

abstract: From Slap Shot: James L. Balsillie, the Canadian billionaire who was already offering $212.5 million to buy the Phoenix Coyotes — some $62 million more than the next-highest bid — increased his offer by another $30 million.

headline: Bank of America Still Tops in Assets
abstract: Bank of America remains the largest banking institution in the United States by total assets, The Houston Business Journal reported, an analysis released Wednesday by SNL Financial.

abstract: Britain needs to be patient in selling stakes in two of its biggest banks, the body managing the holdings said, refusing to give much detail of an exit that could cost taxpayers billions of pounds.

abstract: Federal prosecutors have asked a judge to delay ruling on evidence against former Bear Stearns hedge fund manager Ralph Cioffi, saying they need more time to develop new evidence that they believe is more important than they previously thought.

abstract: It’s been two weeks since I started “Take Back the Beep,” a campaign to flood the four big wireless companies with complaints. Has it had any effect on the carriers?

abstract: Aviva, the British insurer, reported a stronger-than-expected half-year profit Thursday, helped by cost cuts, and announced plans to slash its dividend and partly float Dutch unit Delta Lloyd to bolster its capital.

abstract: Microsoft has approved a proposal to allow shareholders to vote on its executives’ compensation, as U.S. corporations’ pay policies come under scrutiny in the wake of the financial crisis.

abstract: IControl Networks has raised $23 million to develop its home security system, CNet News reported. The system also allows people to control home energy through the Web and mobile devices.

abstract: For videophiles who simply want to calibrate their TVs without knowing the theory behind their actions, there’s now an easy-to-use tuning disc available.

abstract: The fall bookselling season is well underway – led by Dan Brown’s latest thriller and Ted Kennedy’s memoirs.

abstract: The Texas financier R. Allen Stanford, awaiting trial on charges that he led a $7 billion investor fraud, was granted a transfer Monday from a private Texas jail to a federal one closer to his lawyers in downtown Houston.

abstract: Intel has acquired software company RapidMind in an effort to push development of programs that can exploit the power of Intel’s multicore processors.

headline: Microsoft Chases Unknown Scammers Through the Courts
abstract: Five lawsuits filed against John Does on Thursday will give the software company subpoena power to help track down purveyors of Internet malware.

headline: Will New Limits Put Energy Traders on Firing Line?
abstract: If the Commodity Futures Trading Commission moves to limit the activities of energy traders to curb speculation, the result could be harmful, Breakingviews argues.

abstract: A federal bankruptcy judge in New York has cleared the way for The Journal Register Company, a newspaper publisher, to emerge from Chapter 11 protection.

headline: Google’s Domestic Economic Indicators
abstract: dd to your list of alternative economic indicators some new Google Domestic Trends on Google Finance.

headline: ‘Lost Symbol’ Also a Big Hit on Kindle, But How Big?
abstract: Dan Brown’s “Lost Symbol” was a big hit on Kindle, too.

headline: Underwriters in Vonage I.P.O. Are Fined
abstract: An independent securities industry regulator on Tuesday announced fines totaling $425,000 against three Wall Street firms related to the alleged mishandling of the 2006 initial public offering of Vonage Holdings.

headline: Bank Woes Deepening in Europe
abstract: As big U.S. banks show signs of recovery, some counterparts overseas are sinking into a spiral of losses that has prompted the E.U. to consider a more aggressive approach to cleaning up its banking system.

headline: Twitter Restores Service After Attack
abstract: The popular microblogging site crashed on Thursday morning after unknown attackers flooded the site with data requests. Service seemed to have been largely restored by early evening.

headline: Montreal Financier Charged in Ponzi Scheme Is Arrested
abstract: A Montreal financial adviser, Earl Jones, was arrested Monday on charges of theft and fraud, The Globe and Mail reported, as investigators allege that he embezzled millions of dollars in a $46 million Ponzi scheme.

headline: Freedom Communications to File for Bankruptcy This Week
abstract: Freedom Communications is expected to file for bankruptcy this week under a plan that will hand the owner of the Orange County Register and 30 other newspapers to its lenders, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

headline: S.E.C. Proposes a Curb on ‘Pay to Play’
abstract: The S.E.C. will propose new rules to bar investment advisers who have made campaign contributions to an elected official in a position to hire money managers from managing public pension programs for two years, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: July Heat Wilts Newsprint
abstract: Nine newspapers ceased printing in July.

headline: L.A. Prosecutors Offer Timeline to Prove They Pursued Polanski
abstract: Los Angeles prosecutors offer a timeline to prove that they pursued Roman Polanski over the lsat 31 years.

headline: The Estate Tax: A New Conspiracy Theory
abstract: The tax on rich people’s estates disappears altogether in 2010, before reappearing in full force in 2011. Both tax changes have implications for government coffers.

headline: To Help Conan, NBC Moves ‘Wanted’
abstract: One week after scoring especially low ratings with a special about hunting terrorists called “Wanted,” NBC will move a second edition of the series from 10 p.m. next Monday to 9.

headline: Former Joost Chief Joins Index Ventures
abstract: Mike Volpi, the Silicon Valley executive who recently resigned as chief executive of online video start-up Joost, has made a quick transition, joining Joost investor Index Ventures as a partner.

headline: Prosecutors Present Evidence of Fraud in Cioffi Case
abstract: Prosecutors say they have evidence that shows Ralph Cioffi deceived investors and his firm, Bear Stearns, in pledging assets in a hedge fund he ran to obtain a loan for a Florida real estate project.

headline: Dutch Look to Sell Fortis Assets to BNP, Report Says
abstract: The Dutch government is mulling a plan to sell Fortis Bank Nederland assets to France’s BNP Paribas in order to win regulatory approval for a merger of ABN Amro and Fortis Bank Nederland, a Dutch newspaper reported.

headline: First Gizmodo, Then Engadget, Now GDGT
abstract: GDGT, a new site for the gadget-obsessed, differs from predecessors Engadget or Gizmodo by aspiring to be a gadget-oriented social network.
